English: Do you hate flying in the sky?

Japanese:
ああ…　どうも　俺は
高いところが　苦手らしい
English:
Yeah, apparently, I’m not really
good with high places.

Japanese:
それは　大変だな
コーダは　高いところ
平気だぞー　しかし？
English:
That’s bad.
Coda’s fine with high places though.

Japanese:
なら　おまえが操縦しろ
いや　むしろしてくれ…
English:
Then you fly the ship.
I need a break...

Japanese:
んー　やるぞ　しかし！
リカルドに　頼まれたぞ　しかし！
English:
Okay! Leave it to Coda though!
Ricardo, give me the steering wheel though!

Japanese:
いや　待て待て！
ただの冗談だ！
English:
Hey, wait a second!
I was just kidding!

Japanese:
…………はぁ
ほら　さっさと行くぞ…
English:
Sigh...
Let’s just head out...

Japanese:
んー　リカルド
なんだか疲れてるなー　しかし
English:
Hmm...
Ricardo looks tired though...

Japanese:
サルより　リカルド　まだマシ
キュキュ　命拾い
助かた…
English:
Close...
Ricardo saved QQ’s life once again.

Japanese:
キュキュ　こんなところで
死にたくない…
English: QQ doesn’t want to die here.

Japanese: 鼻息荒いイリア
English: Excited Illia

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese:
むっふーッ！
見てなさいよー　マティウス！
English: Hmph! Just you wait, Mattheus!

Japanese:
すごいね　イリア
…特に鼻息が
English: Whoa, you sure are excited, Illia.

Japanese:
そりゃあ　あんた
とうとう　最後の決戦よ？
気合も入るってなもんよ！
English:
Duh, it’s the final battle, after all.
I need to have some fighting spirit.

Japanese:
ねえ　そんなに力　入れてると
マティウスと戦う前に
疲れちゃうよ？
English:
But wouldn’t mustering the spirit way
before fighting Mattheus just make
you even more tired?

Japanese:
いひひひひ！
そのくらいで　ちょうどいいのよ
ハンデってヤツ！
English:
Hee-hee-hee!
Even better!
It’s gonna be a handicap!

Japanese:
怒りと使命に燃えた　あたしの弾丸
かる～く百発は
ぶち込んでやるんだから！
English:
Let rage and obligation fuel my spirit,
and my bullets will always hit their mark!

Japanese: むっふーッ！
English: Mmmph!

Japanese:
本当にすごいね　イリア
…の鼻息
English: Your... excitement is really amazing.

Japanese:
当ったり前だっての！
ほら　あんたも気合入れなさい！
English: Naturally! Now, you gotta get fired up too!

Japanese:
う…　うん…
頑張ってみるよ
English: O-Okay, I’ll try my best.

Japanese: むっふーッ！
English: Mmmph!

Japanese: 気が引けるなぁ…
English: It Feels Uncomfortable...

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
なんだか　教団兵や王都兵と
戦うのって　気が引けるなぁ…
English:
For some reason, I feel uncomfortable
fighting the Imperial Army and the Church...

Japanese:
ルカくん　キミはまだ
そんなこと　言ってるの？
English: You are still saying such things, Ruca?

Japanese:
ああ…　コンウェイの言う通りだ
戦場で　敵は選べん
English:
Exactly what Kongwei said.
You can’t pick your enemies on the battlefield.

Japanese:
それは　相手も同じ
戦場で　遠慮するようなヤツは
命が　いくつあっても足りんぞ
English:
And that also includes your allies.
You won’t last long if you don’t give
your all on the battlefield.

Japanese:
でも　この戦いの発端は
僕とマティウスの　問題なのに
関係ない人を　巻き込むなんて…
English:
But this war started because of
me and Mattheus...
To get others involved is...

Japanese:
…………
部外者のボクが言うのも
なんだけどさ
English:
...
Yet here I am, an outsider...

Japanese:
今　ここで戦いをためらうのは
これまで　消えていった魂に対して
失礼なんじゃない？
English:
Would it not be be rude to those who lost
their lives in this war if you hesitate now?
Huh?

Japanese:
キミが　責任を感じる
必要なんてないと思うよ
English: I do not think you should feel guilty about this.

Japanese:
そう
起こってしまった戦争の
原因を考えても　取り返しなどつかん
English:
Indeed. It has already happened. 
We can’t reverse this, only bring an end to it.

Japanese:
こうなってしまった以上　ルカ
今のおまえにできることは　誰よりも先に
創世力を　手に入れること
English:
And the very least you can do, Ruca,
is obtain the Genesis before anyone else does.

Japanese:
それが　早ければ早いほど
奪われる魂も　少なくなる
ボクなら　そう考えるよ
English:
And I believe that the faster we get to it,
the more lives will be spared.

Japanese: …そうだね
English: You’re right...

Japanese:
うん！
ありがとう
コンウェイ　リカルド
English:
Yes!
Thank you guys.

Japanese: ハスタについて
English: About Hasta

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese: コーダ
English: Coda

Japanese:
あの野郎　ホント…
あ～！　せいせいしたッ！
English:
That bastard is really...
Ahh... I feel cleaner now!

Japanese:
ああ　なんつーか
胸のつかえが　取れた気分だぜ
English:
Tell me about it. Felt like a
weight’s off my chest now.

Japanese:
そんなこと言って
ホントは　ふたりとも
寂しいんじゃないの？
English:
You both say that, but in truth
you’re both sad, aren’t you?

Japanese:
冗談でしょ！
金輪際　関りたくないっての！
English:
You’re kidding, right?
I don’t want to get involved with
that thing ever again!

Japanese:
まったくだ
オレは　もう前世と現世で関わった
English:
Damn, right.
I’m already involved with him in
this life and my previous life.

Japanese:
来世でまで　あの野郎の
ツラなんざ　おがみたくねェぜ！
English: Cielo knows he’ll be in my next life too.

Japanese: じゃあ　リカルドは？
English: Then how about you, Ricardo?

Japanese:
いちいち　倒した相手のことなど
憶えていたら　キリがないが
ヤツのことは　忘れられんだろうな
English:
Out of all the people I’ve taken down,
I don’t think I’ll be able to forget someone like him.

Japanese:
忘れたくても　忘れさせてくれん
ただ　俺も
二度と関りたくはない
English:
Even if I want to, I can’t.
I just don’t want to get involved
with him ever again.

Japanese:
でも　コーダなー
あいつのヘンな話
わりと好きだったなー　しかし
English:
But Coda did like how
he speaks weirdly though.

Japanese:
ああ…
それが　ヤツを忘れたくても
忘れさせてくれん　所以だな
English:
Oh...
that’s something about him that
you can’t forget even if you wanted to.

Japanese:
僕も　ハスタから受けた
傷の痛みは　忘れられないよ
English:
I’ll never forget the pain from
the wound that Hasta gave me.

Japanese:
…でも　僕は憎いのとは違う気がする
困った人だったとは思うけど
嫌いだったかどうかは　わからないや
English:
But I don’t hate him.
He was a troubled man, yes,
but I don’t know if I hate him for it.

Japanese:
それは　あいつが　どーでもいい
ヤツだったってことだなー　しかし
English:
Then does that mean that
you don’t really care about him?

Japanese:
うん…
そうなのかもね
English: Yeah... that might be it.

Japanese: またリカルドを慰めてみる
English: Comforting Ricardo Once Again

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
リカルド…
ガードルのことだけど…
English: About Gardle...

Japanese: 言うな！
English: Don’t!

...
Sorry...

Japanese:
感傷に　ひたっている時間などない
泣いたり叫んだりは　後でもできる
今はマティウスとの戦いに　集中しろ
English:
We don’t have time for mourning.
I can do that afterward. For now, 
we have to focus on Mattheus!

Japanese: う…　うん
English: Right.

Japanese:
…そして　戦いのあとで　酒の酌をしろ
いいな？
English:
You can pour one out for me afterwards,
understand?

Japanese:
うん！
わかったよ　リカルド
English:
Alright.
I understand, Ricardo.

Japanese: 残るはマティウス！
English: All that’s Left is Mattheus!

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: キュキュ
English: QQ

Japanese: コーダ
English: Coda

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
もうすぐ終わる
僕たちの戦いが…
English: We’re almost at the end...

Japanese: 早く　ぶっ飛ばしに行きましょ！
English: Let’s go kick her ass!

Japanese:
ああ　腕が鳴るぜ
おめェら　全員オレが守ってやらァ！
English:
My arms are shaking...
I’ll definitely protect you all!

Japanese:
は～　やっと仕舞いかぁ
正直　ここまで登って来るん
しんどかったで
English:
Sigh... We’re finally at the end.
Ta be honest it was really hard
makin’ our way up here.

Japanese:
フン…　みんな準備は万全か？
今なら　まだ引き返せるぞ？
English:
Is everyone ready?
We can still turn back now.

Japanese:
…だってさ
どうする　キュキュ？
English:
So he says...
what do you think, QQ?

Japanese:
キュキュ　みんな　一緒
ずとずと　ついてく　言った
約束　守る
English:
Everyone let QQ come along.
QQ promise to protect everyone.

Japanese:
あ～　コーダ
お腹空いたぞー　しかし？
メシは　もうないのかー　しかし？
English:
Ahh... Coda’s hungry though.
When are we eating lunch?

Japanese:
ご飯か…　英気を養うにはいいかも
みんなは　体　大丈夫？
ムリしちゃダメよ？
English:
A meal sounds nice for keeping up our energy.
Is everyone all right?
Do not force yourselves.

Japanese: …じゃあ　みんな
English: Well, everyone...

Japanese: 行こう！
English: Let’s go!

Japanese: 着替えたい
English: A Change of Clothes

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese:
ガラム火山といい　ガルポスといい
暑いところが　続くね
僕の服じゃあ　汗だくだよ
English:
Man, we’ve been going from one hot place to another 
and my clothes are all soaked with sweat.

Japanese: 大変そうだな
English: How terrible.

Japanese:
リカルドの方が　暑そうだよ
ロングコートまで　着込んじゃってるしさ
その下に　長袖まで着てるんでしょ？
English:
You’re one to talk. Aren’t you wearing long sleeves 
under that long coat of yours?

Japanese:
戦場では　この格好の方がいいんだ
厚い布地が　ちょうどいい
弾よけになるからな
English:
This kind of clothing is appropriate on the battlefield.
Its thick fabric can even repel bullets.

Japanese:
ただ　暑いのと重いのと臭いのを
ガマンすればの話だがな
English:
But it’s also a matter of enduring the heat, heaviness,
and stinkiness of wearing such clothes.

Japanese:
いや…
それが　ガマンできないって
話なんだけど…
English: But I can’t endure that, though.

Japanese:
…で　コンウェイは大丈夫なの？
すごく暑そうに見えるんだけど
その服…
English: How about you, Kongwei, you alright in those?

Japanese:
こう見えて　ボクの服は薄手でね
この程度の暑さなら
特に　支障はないよ
English:
These might look heavy but they are actually quite light. 
This amount of heat is no problem.

Japanese:
コンウェイ　おまえ
そういえば　ガラム火山でも
涼しそうにしていたな…
English:
On that note, even you looked comfortable while 
in Garam...

Japanese:
うわっ　リカルド　汗くさッ！！
っていうか　汗以外の
臭いの方が　くっさ！
English:
Ewww Ricardo you stink of sweat... 
Heck, you stink of more than sweat!

Japanese:
リカルド　そのコート
洗濯しなさいよ！
English: Go wash that damn coat of yours!

Japanese:
ああ　そうだな
……………そうしよう
English: Oh... Now that you mention it, I should...

Japanese:
コンウェイは
また　涼しそうね
汗も　かいてないし
English:
Damn, Kongwei, you sure look comfortable in that. 
You don’t stink either.

Japanese:
元々　汗をかかない
体質なんだ
English: I have never been a sweaty person, after all.

Japanese:
あんた　ガラム火山でも
そんなんじゃなかった？
English: Even when we were in Garam?

Japanese:
この暑さで　汗かかないなんて
ホントは　あんた
とっくに　死んでんじゃないの？
English:
So you’re telling me that you didn’t sweat in a volcano? 
Are you even alive?

Japanese:
そういうイリアだって　涼しそうだよ
スカーフが　ちょっと暑そうな以外
風通し良さそうだし
English:
You’re one to talk, Illia. Your clothes 
look comfortable, scarf aside.

Japanese:
スカーフしないと　あたしの村じゃ
砂ぼこりが　入っちゃうのよね～
このあたりだと　そんな心配ないけどさ
English:
Back where I’m from, you need a scarf if you don’t 
want dust getting in your clothes... 
Though, that’s not much of a problem here.

Japanese:
リカルドだけじゃなくて
アンジュも　スパーダも
暑さで　参ってきてるみたいよ
English:
By the way, Ange and Spada look
pissed off in the heat.

Japanese:
エルとキュキュさんは
元気だね
あの格好も　涼しそうだもん
English:
In contrast, Hermie and QQ are fine. Their clothes look 
so comfortable.

Japanese:
エルは　肌出しすぎだってのよ
でも　お風呂のときが　楽しみね
あの子のわき腹！
English:
Hermie’s showing too much skin! I’m sooo 
looking forward to washing her side.

Japanese:
ああ　日焼けの跡
残りそうだよね
English: Oh right, she’s bound to get sunburn from those.

Japanese:
いひひひひ
ぜひ　からかってやろ～っと♪
English: I’m soooo totally gonna tease her～

Japanese:
イリアだって　お腹だけ
日に焼けちゃうんじゃないのかなぁ
English: I wonder if Illia’s stomach gets sunburned sometimes.

Japanese: 寒すぎッ
English: Too Cold

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: う～…　寒ィな
English: Cold...

Japanese:
そうね
冷え性の私には
ちょっと　ツラいかも
English:
You are correct, it might be a bit difficult for
me because I am pretty sensitive to cold.

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese:
どうしたの　エル？
なんだか　表情の割に
静かだけど…
English:
What is wrong, Hermie?
You have been quiet for a while now.

Japanese:
おおぅ　エル！
大丈夫か？
唇が　真紫色だぜ！？
English:
You alright over there, Hermie?
Your lips are turning purple.

Japanese:
さ…　さむさむ…
さささささむ…　い…
English: C-C-C-C-C-C-C-Cold...

Japanese: なーんだよ　だらしねェなぁ
English:
That’s coz you wear those
skimpy ass clothes, Hermie.

Japanese:
エル　あなた
もう少し　服装考えなさいよ
English:
You should give more thought
to your choice of clothes.

Japanese:
そんなん　しゃぁないやん！！
ほな　ウチにも厚着させてくれっちゅう
話やで…
English:
Th-That ain’t it!
Yer jus’ tellin’ me ta wear warmer clothes!

Japanese:
あ…　あかん！　ウチ　凍え死ぬ！
コーダでも抱きしめて　温かなろ！
English:
This ain’t g-good!
Ah-Ah’m f-f-freezin’ ta d-death!
Ah’ll hug C-Coda t-ta g-get warm...

Japanese:
そういや　イリアとキュキュも
寒そうに　ふるえてたな
あいつらも　薄着だから
English:
Even Illia and QQ are shivering
coz they’re dressed lightly.

Japanese:
ルカくんと　リカルドさんは
暑い地方じゃ　大変だったみたいだけど
今は　快適みたいね
English:
On the other hand, Ruca and Sir Ricardo are
comfortable here compared to when they
were in the south.

Japanese:
アンジュも　平気そうだな
…………あれ？
おい　コンウェイ！
English:
And you seem fine, Ange--
H-Hey! K-Kongwei!?

Japanese: あんた　寒さは平気なのか？
English: You doing fine over there?

Japanese:
ゼンゼン　平気さ
この服　見た目より保温性が高いから
別に寒くはないよ
English:
Perfectly fine, as you can see, my clothes
have a high thermal insulation property
so I am not at all cold.

Japanese:
それに　ボク　元々
寒さに　強い体質だからさ
English: Furthermore, I am already used to it.

Japanese:
私も寒いのは　平気だけど
暑いのが　苦手なのよねぇ…
すぐアセモが　できちゃうし
English:
I handle the cold better, however I cannot
tolerate the heat. If it’s too hot, I might get
rashes from the sweat...

Japanese:
お！　アセモ…
そ…　それって
もしかして　できるのは…？
English: S-Sweat r-rash!? B-By that you mean...?

Japanese:
はいはい
スパーダくんの　ご想像通り
バスト部分によ　バ・ス・ト
English:
Yes, yes, Spada, as you can imagine,
they form in my bust area.
My. Bust. Area.

Japanese: デヘヘ……
え～と…　オッホン！
English: In any case... Ahem.

Japanese:
ねえ　スパーダくん
それ以上は　想像しないでくれる？
English: I would be grateful if you stopped at that.

Japanese: …おっと　失敬失敬
English: Oh, sorry haha...

Japanese:
っていうか　あなたも
かなり　寒いんじゃないの？
ちゃんと　エリを閉めればいいのに…
English:
At any rate, you are feeling pretty cold,
are you not?
Why not button up your collar?

Japanese: これは　これでいいんだよ
English: I’m fine...

Japanese:
さあ　とっとと探索終えて
街に戻ろうぜ　うぃ～　寒ぃぃ…
English:
Let’s get this search over with 
so we can go back to town. 
Ughh... c-c-cold...

Japanese: チトセについて
English: About Chitose

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
やれやれ　みんなの間に
流れる空気が　重いぜ
これも　あのチトセって女のせいだな
English:
Sheesh, the atmosphere between
everyone’s hella heavy...
It’s all cause of that Chitose chick.

Japanese:
あーあ
あいつ　見た目はかわいいのによぉ
ったく余計なことしてくれるな
English:
Man, I thought she was pretty
cute, too... This is too much.

Japanese:
どういうつもりなのかな
彼女…
English:
Whatever could be going through 
that young lady’s mind?

Japanese:
おそらく　あれは俺たちに
互いを　疑い合わせるための
デマカセだろう
English:
It’s likely that she’s planning on
making us doubt each other by
saying such a thing.

Japanese:
ああ　そうに違いねェ
あんなマユなし女の言うこと
気にしなくていいって
English:
No doubt about it, that’s why we
shouldn’t worry about what
that eyebrow-less woman says.

Japanese:
いえ　私が　気にしてるのは
あの歳で　前髪パッツンなのは
女として　どうなのかってことよ
English:
No, rather, I am more curious as to why she 
would have that haircut at such a young age.

Japanese:
あの歳よ？　どう見たって　１０代後半
ハタチ手前なのに　前髪パッツンなんて
まさしく微妙…
English:
Look at her! No matter how you frame
it, having bangs as a teenager is indeed
questionable, is it not?

Japanese:
いえ　どちらかと言えば
ハズレ…
English: No... it is unquestionably tacky!

Japanese:
…アンジュ
おまえ　身内以外には
ずいぶん厳しい　物言いをするんだな
English:
Ange... You’re unexpectedly harsh when
talking about someone’s appearance.

Japanese:
でもよ　それを言ったら
アンジュだって
結構　前髪パッツンじゃねェ？
English:
Now that you mention it, what about you?
Don’t you have bangs too?

Japanese:
…………
もしかして　アンジュ
彼女の黒髪が　うらやましいのか？
English:
Don’t tell me, Ange... Are you perhaps jealous
of that girl’s hair...?

Japanese:
…ハッ！　私　クセっ毛だから
ああいう　ストレートの黒髪が
うらやましくて　ねたましくて　つい…
English:
I-I...! I have curly hair, so after seeing her
straight black hair I cannot help but...
Yes I am...

Japanese:
なんだ　ただのねたみかよ…
意外と　アンジュも大人げねェのな
English:
What? So you’re just jealous, huh?
You sure are unexpectedly immature, Ange.

Japanese:
仕方ないでしょ？　前髪パッツンは
自分の中の　失われた少女っぽさを
取り戻すための　髪型なんだから
English:
What else should I feel? This is a haircut that
is supposed to bring out my long gone youth!

Japanese:
だから　大人げなくても
いいんですよ～だ！
English: Which is why it is fine if I act immature for once!

Japanese:
フン…　ムリしてガキのように
振舞わんでも　いいだろうに
English:
Hah, you don’t have to act
like an immature brat, though...

Japanese:
いいじゃん
ああいう　アンジュの態度って
男として見たら　かわいくねェ？
English:
Let her be, man. That sort of attitude
can be pretty cute, too...

Japanese:
そう思わせるよう　計算しているのだ
アンジュはな
English:
Considering it’s Ange, I can’t help but
think that her attitude’s intentional.

Japanese: うぇへ～　計算ずくかよ！
English: Really? “Intentional?”

Japanese:
おかげで　先ほどまでの
重い空気も　少しは軽くなったろう
English:
Indeed. Thanks to her reaction, the heavy 
atmosphere has lifted quite a bit.

Japanese:
…………
アンジュって　すげェ…
ってか　女って　怖えェ…
English:
Ange’s amazing... rather, 
women sure are scary...

Japanese:
しかも　それを見破る
リカルドも　すげェ…
オレ　まだまだ修行が足りねェな…
English:
And to even see through that means you’re pretty 
amazing yourself, Ricardo... Looks like I still need 
more experience...!

Japanese: オズバルドって？２
English: Oswald is...? 2

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
…そういえば　先ほどのグリゴリ兵
オズバルドとやらの名を
口にしていたな
English:
That Grigori soldier back
there mentioned Oswald’s name...

Japanese:
ああ…
さっきのロボットに　乗ってたヤツ
確かに　そう言ってたよね
English:
Oh, that guy in the robot... 
I think he did, yeah.

Japanese:
どういうお人なの？
そのオズバルドさんって
English: I wonder what sort of person this Oswald is...

Japanese:
いや　まあ
人っていうか　豚っていうか…
English: He’s... Less of a person and more of a pig...

Japanese:
とにかく　おっさんよ！
いやらしい　ヒゲ生やして
でっぷり太ったね！
English:
At any rate! He’s this nasty old man with some 
yee yee ass beard and he’s really fat...

Japanese:
見かけたら　警告抜きで
ハチの巣にしてやるんだから！
English:
I swear, if I see him again, I’ll definitely make him
holier than Ange!

Japanese:
おっさんにヒゲか　やれやれ…
そこだけなら　俺も当てはまるんだがな
まあ　太ってないだけマシか
English:
So an old man with a beard, huh...
I suppose that could also apply to me,
but I’m not really fat.

Japanese:
確か　ハルトマンさんは
軍の高官だと　仰っていたけど
本当にそうなの？
English:
I recall Hartman saying that he was a
high-ranking official... Is that true?

Japanese:
転生者研究所で
エラッそうにしてたもん
でっぷりお腹を　ゆすりながらさぁ
English:
Well, he was acting all high-and-mighty in the
Research Laboratory, beer belly shaking and all.

Japanese:
それに　軍基地にあった
あのロボットを　持ち出せるんだから
やっぱ　軍のお偉いさんなんじゃないの？
English:
And that robot looked like the one 
we saw from Naohs Base, right?
So maybe he really is a higher-up?

Japanese:
フン…　そして今や
グリゴリの民をも
自由に動かせる立場というわけか
English:
Hmm... and now, he’s in a position
to command the Grigori at will.

Japanese:
もしかすると　マティウス以上に
厄介な相手かもしれん
English:
He might be another enemy that we’ll have
to worry about aside from Mattheus.

Japanese:
それは　ど～かなぁ？
なんか小悪党　丸出しって感じで
イマイチ　印象薄いのよね～
English:
I wonder～? I think he’s more of a mini-boss.
Well, that’s the impression that he gives off,
at least.

Japanese:
油断はしちゃダメよ　イリア
人は見かけによらないものだし
English:
Do not underestimate him, Illia.
People are not always what they seem.

Japanese: へいへい　気をつけますよ～だ
English: Aight, aight, I’ll be careful～.

Japanese:
心配ですね
敵の力が　増しているような
気がしてなりません
English:
I am worried, it seems that our enemies
are gradually growing stronger as we
move forward...

Japanese:
だが連中も　一枚岩とは言えないようだ
俺たちに　かまけるヒマなど
なさそうにも思えるがな
English:
At the very least, I’m sure they’re not
working together and it doesn’t seem
that they have time to deal with us.

Japanese: だといいのですが…
English: I hope so...

Japanese: 秘密のお楽しみ
English: Esoteric Enjoyments

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
ねぇねぇ　宿の人が言ってた
「別料金のお楽しみ」って
なんのことかな？
English:
Hey, what did the innkeeper mean
when they said “extra fun?”

Japanese:
おっほ～　ようやくルカくんも
そういうことに
興味を持ってくれたんだねェ
English:
Oho～
So you’ve finally gotten an
interest in that, huh, Ruca?

Japanese:
オレさまは　嬉しいよ
うんうん
English: I’m very proud of you～

Japanese:
なに　その満面の笑み…
やっぱり　そっち方面の話なの？
English:
What’s with that smile, Spada?
You’re talking about “that”, aren’t you?

Japanese:
そんなの　わかんねーだろ？
ただの手品ショーかもしれねェじゃん？
English:
Hey, hey, it might be a magic show or something.
We don’t know if it’s “that.”

Japanese:
手品ショーなら
それはそれで　楽しそうだけどね
English: But a magic show sounds really fun.

Japanese:
後で　コッソリ抜け出して
そのお楽しみを　味わってみようぜ！
ヒャハハハハ！
English:
Then let’s sneak out later and check it out.
Wahahaha!

Japanese:
おい　ふたりで
なにを企んでいる？
English: Hey, what are you two scheming?

Japanese: あ…　いや　別にィ
English: Oh... uh... nothing.
Nothing...

Japanese:
スパーダ
おまえは笑い方で
なにを考えてるのかが　わかる
English: Spada, I know that expression.

Japanese:
考えを　読まれるようでは
裏をかかれるぞ
せいぜい　気をつけるんだな
English:
Get it through your head, an opponent that 
knows what you’re thinking can easily get 
the better of you. Be careful.

Japanese:
ヘッ　ご忠告ありがとよ！
ちぇ…　興ざめしちまった
ルカ　行こーぜェ
English:
Heh. Thanks for the heads up, old man!
Tch... spoilsport.
C’mon let’s move, Ruca.

Japanese:
あのサービスで　１００ガルドか…
クソッ　少々高くつき過ぎた！
English:
So that service is worth 100 gald?
Damn it! It’s too expensive!

Japanese:
まあ　なんにせよ
ガキどもには　まだ早すぎるな
あのサービスは…
English:
At any rate, it’s a little too early for
those kids to experience that...

Japanese:
ぜぇってぇ「別料金のお楽しみ」
内容を確かめてやるぜェ
ヒャハハハハ！　ヒャッホー！
English:
I DEFINITELY have to know what that
“extra fun” is! Hyahahahaha! YAHOO!

Japanese: シアンの様子
English: Sian’s Situation

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese: シアン
English: Sian

Japanese:
は～い　シアン
元気にやってる？
English: Hiiii, Sian! You doing well?

Japanese:
村の人に
迷惑とか　かけてへんか？
English: Yer not causin’ the village trouble, are ya?

Japanese:
…あ　ああ
おかげさまでね
みんなに親切にして　もらってるよ
English:
Uh... no... It’s actually thanks to 
you that they’ve been kind to me.

Japanese:
ふーん　ケガの具合も
ええようやな
自分　仕事とか手伝っとるんか？
English:
Hm... Looks like yer wounds are healin’
right. Are ya helpin’ ’em out?

Japanese:
あ…　当たり前だろ
ボクだって　一応
この村の一員なんだぞ！
English:
O-Of course I am! At the very least,
I’m a member of this village!

Japanese:
ケルとベロは　不審者が来ないよう
村の周りを　見張ってるし
ボクだって　いろいろ働いてるんだ！
English:
Cer and Berus are patrolling the village and
I’m taking up all sorts of jobs and helping out
in the village too!

Japanese: いろいろって　なんやの？
English: Like what?

Japanese:
部屋を掃除したり
小さな子どもたちの　世話をしたりさ
English:
Like cleaning their rooms and
taking care of the small kids.

Japanese:
あと　この村に来た兵士も
ちゃんと追っ払ってるよ
English:
And driving out the soldiers that
try to come close to this village.

Japanese:
案外　ちゃんとやってんじゃん
感心感心
English: You’re doing better than I thought! Great work!

Japanese:
あ…　そろそろ時間だ
行かなきゃ…
English: Oh, it’s time. I better go...

Japanese: 行くって　どこヘ？
English: Go where?

Japanese:
おまえの母親が
この時間になると　ボクを散歩に
連れてってくれるんだ
English:
Your mom, I accompany her 
on a walk around this time.

Japanese:
そのあと　一緒にご飯を食べたり
体に　ブラシをかけてくれたり
なんだか…　いろいろしてくれるんだ…
English:
And then we both eat lunch together 
and then she brushes my hair... 
Lot’s of stuff...

Japanese: それって…
English: Isn’t that...

Japanese:
ペット扱いじゃん！！
完全に！
English: She’s just treating him like a pet!

Japanese: ケルとベロ危機一髪
English: Cer and Berus’ Close Call

Japanese: コーダ
English: Coda

Japanese: シアン
English: Sian

Japanese:
ぬふぬふ　おまえ
どうして　コーダを
見つめるかー　しかし？
English: Meheheh, why are you looking at Coda though?

Japanese:
おまえらって
一体　何者なんだ？
English: What are you, anyway?

Japanese:
おまえ　いいこと聞くな
コーダはコーダだ
よく覚えておけ　しかし
English:
Good question! Coda is Coda! 
Make sure to remember it though!

Japanese:
いや　おまえだけのことじゃない！
えーっと　ミュース族って言ったっけ？
おまえたち全員のことだよ！
English:
No, not you! I’m talking about the uh... 
was it the Muse Clan? Anyways, 
I’m talking about all of you!

Japanese:
なんなんだよ　一体！
どうして　揃いも揃って
あんなに食い意地が　張ってるんだ！
English:
What are you? 
Why do all of you eat so much?

Japanese:
おう　コーダとコーダの愉快な仲間たち
すぅんごい　たくさんメシ食うぞー？
うらやましいだろー　しかし
English:
Yeah! Coda and Coda’s amazing friends
eaaats a lot, y’know? Are you jealous though～?

Japanese:
うらやましいもんか！
おまえたち　一体なに考えてるんだよ！
English:
Me? JEALOUS? As if! I don’t know what’s
going on through your kind’s mind!

Japanese:
おまえの仲間たち　ちょっとスキを見せたら
ボクのケルとベロを
焼いて食べようとしたんだぞ！
English:
Your friends tried to cook Cer and
Berus when I wasn’t looking!

Japanese:
ああ　おまえと一緒の　あの生き物な
案外　うまいかもしれんぞー　しかし？
ぬふぬふ～　あの生き物なぁ…
English:
Oh, the animals that were always with you?
Who knows? They might be surprisingly tasty though!
MFufufufu... meat...

Japanese:
おっと　コーダ
用事を思い出す　用事があったー
失礼するぞ　しかし？
English:
Oops! Coda forgot that Coda’s supposed 
to be doing something. Excuse Coda though!

Japanese:
ちょっと待て　このケダモノ！
そのまな板と包丁
なにに　使うつもりだ！
English:
Hey... hold on a second, you rat! 
What are you going to do with that knife!?

Japanese: 戻って来てくれてよかった(訳)
English: I’m Glad You’re Back

Japanese: コーダ
English: Coda

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: キュキュ
English: QQ

Japanese:
ルカ
よく戻ってきたな　しかし！
English: Ruca, you came back though!

Japanese:
あ～ら　別に戻って来なくたって
ホントのところは
全然　困らなかったけどね
English:
Oh...? You didn’t have to come back though?
It’s not like I was troubled at all.

Japanese:
あはは…
イリアは　そういうと
思ってたよ
English: Hahaha, I thought you’d say that.

Japanese:
だったら　戻って来なきゃ
良かったじゃん
English: Then you shouldn’t have come back at all!

Japanese:
さっきと　言ってることが違うよ
さっきは僕のこと　待っててくれたって
言ったじゃないか
English:
But that’s not what you told me earlier.
What you said was, “I’ve always been
waiting for you.”

Japanese:
な～に言ってんのよ
あたしは「みんなが」待ってるって
言ったの
English:
What the heck are you saying!?
I said, “we’ve all been waiting for you!”

Japanese:
「あたしが」待ってたなんて
言ってないでしょ
English:
I didn’t say that “I” was waiting
for you at all!

Japanese:
あはは！　うん　そうだね
あ～　良かった　いつものイリアだ
English:
Hahaha, that’s true.
Oh, I’m so glad that you’re still the same.

Japanese:
いつものイリアに
また会えて　僕　嬉しいよ…
English: I’m so happy to see the usual Illia...

Japanese:
…………
フ～ンだ！
ナマイキ　言っちゃって！
English:
Bleh!
Don’t get ahead of yourself, dummy!

Japanese:
そーだそーだ！
ルカ　ナマイキだぞー　しかし！
English:
Yeah, yeah, Ruca!
Don’t get ahead of yourself though!

Japanese:
へへッ　イリアのヤツ
照れてやがるぜ
English: Haha, you made Illia embarrassed.

Japanese:
…素直に再会を
喜べばいいものを
English: Why can’t she just be happy to meet you again?

Japanese:
じゃあ　スパーダとリカルドは
喜んでくれてるの？
English: Are you both happy that I came back?

Japanese:
ケッ　最後の最後でオレたちを
信じられなかったクセに
よく言うぜ
English:
Tch, idiot, you couldn’t even
trust us at the last minute.
How dare you.

Japanese:
…この貸しは　返してもらうまで
てめェのそば　離れたりしねェから
覚悟しやがれよ！
English:
I won’t let you out of my sight until you’ve
paid that debt of yours, so get ready!

Japanese: フ…　まあ俺は大人だからな
English:
Hmph, let’s just say that I can tolerate small
tantrums like what you did back there.

Japanese:
ルカがやったような
ガキがかんしゃくを　起こした程度の騒ぎには
寛容だとだけ　言っておこう
English: I’m an adult, after all.

Japanese:
…ふたりとも
ありがとう
English: Thank you, you two.

Japanese:
ルカくん
私たちは　素直に喜んでるのよ？
English: Ruca, just know that we are really happy, okay?

Japanese:
せやで
ウチらは　素直やで～？
English: Yeah, we’re really really really happy, hear?

Japanese: 本当？　嬉しいな…
English: Really? I’m happy...

Japanese:
だって　ルカくんがいないと
イリアとスパーダくんが
もう不機嫌で　不機嫌で…
English:
After all, without you, Illia and
Spada would be very sad...

Japanese:
そうそう
おかげで　めっちゃ雰囲気が
悪なってん
English:
It’s true. The atmosphere among
us was really bad cause of ya.

Japanese:
ホ～ント
ルカくんには　しっかり…
English:
Honestly～
Ruca is really...

Japanese: いじられ役　やってもらわな！
English: Yeah, yer the one they’re supposed ta tease!

Japanese:
え…　それって…
全然　喜べないんだけど…
僕は　いじられないと　ダメってこと？
English:
Huh? But that doesn’t really make
me happy though...
Do I really have to be teased?

Japanese:
よぉ　わかってるやん！
ホンマ　ルカ兄ちゃんは
賢いええ子やなぁ
English:
Glad ya understand.
Yer an awfully clever boy～!

Japanese:
イリア　コーダ　リカルド
アンジュ　エル　ヘンな帽子
ルカと　一緒　うれしい
English:
Illia, Coda, Ricardo, Ange, Hermie,
and weird hat are really happy you’re here.

Japanese:
でも　素直　言わない　恥…？
キュキュは　言う
ルカと　一緒　うれしい！
English:
But they can’t say coz they’re... embarrassed?
QQ will say, she’s glad you’re here.

Japanese: …あ～　ん～　コンウェイ
English: Uh... hmm... Kongwei...

Japanese:
だいたい　わかるでしょ
説明してよ！
English:
Kongwei, you know what I mean.
Can you explain it to him...?

Japanese: …わかったよ　キュキュ
English: All right, QQ.

Japanese:
ルカくん
キミが　戻って来てくれて
みんな　喜んでる
English: Everyone is really glad you are back, Ruca.

Japanese:
このキュキュも
そして　もちろんボクも…
キミは　なにも気に病むことはない
English:
QQ and, of course, me too.
You do not have to worry about anything at all.

Japanese:
この先は　もう迷わなくていい
キミが　必要と思う道を進めば
それが　正しい道だよ
English:
There is no need to wonder from here on out.
Just choose path you think is the best.

Japanese: 道だ！
English: Path!

Japanese:
キミは　キミ自身の力で
自らの魂を　救済したのだから…
English:
After all, you have already redeemed
your soul with your own power...

Japanese:
…戻って来て　良かった
ただいま
みんな…
English:
I’m glad I came back...
Everyone, I’m home...

Japanese: 異能者捕縛適応法について
English: About the Deviant Reformation Act

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese:
あのマティウスって人
どうして　急に引き下がったんだろ？
English: I wonder why Mattheus suddenly left?

Japanese:
そんなの決まってんでしょ？
あれよ　え～っと…
異能者…適応…　なんちゃらってヤツ？
English:
Isn’t that obvious?
The... Deviant-thingy...
What was it again?

Japanese: 異能者捕縛適応法…　かな？
English: The Deviant Reformation Act?

Japanese:
そう　それ！
さすがに　あのマティウスだって
おおっぴらに天術は　使えないでしょ
English:
Yes, that!
With those guys around, even Mattheus can’t use 
Cielan Artes freely.

Japanese: それにしても　迷惑な法律だね
English: Still... What a troublesome law.

Japanese:
…まあ　あたしたちにとってはね
でも　あんたは　知らないんだろうけどさ
異能者は　結構　煙たがられてんのよ
English:
For us, that is.
You probably don’t know, but no one really
likes Deviants.

Japanese: そ…　そうなの？
English: R-Really?

Japanese:
ほら　あたし　逃げながら
異能者の　情報集めてたじゃない？
だから　色々　見聞きして来たのよ
English:
Y’know how I was able to gather a lot of info about the 
Deviant while I was running away from the Church? 
So while I was doing that, I heard a lot of stuff.

Japanese:
その異能の力を使って　強盗したり
大暴れして　人を傷つけちゃったり…
評判悪いのよね
English:
Deviants are infamous for using their own power
to rob, destroy, and hurt others.

Japanese:
…そうなんだ
僕や君が　人に迷惑なんて
かけたりしないと思うんだけど…
English: Oh... but I don’t think we’re really bothering others...

Japanese:
そんなの　知らない人には
わかんないでしょ
English: As if people would know about that!

Japanese:
あたし　銃持ってるけど
あんたを　撃たない保証なんてないもの
English:
I have a gun with me, right? There’s no way to
guarantee that I won’t shoot you.

Japanese:
ええ！？
そ…　そうなのかな…
English: Huh!? I-Is that so?

Japanese:
あたしの育った地方では
銃に手を掛けただけで
攻撃行為って　見なされるんだから
English:
Coz, from where I’m from, handling guns
is considered to be an act of aggression.

Japanese:
それで　相手に撃たれても
文句言えないのよ
自分の常識だけで　物は考えないことね
English:
As long as I’m holding a gun, I can’t complain if 
I end up being shot at. Coz, as long as I have 
these, I’m a threat.

Japanese:
じゃあ　天術が使えるってだけで
恐がられるのも
仕方ないのかな
English:
Then do we really have no choice if we end up
being feared, just because we can use 
Cielan Artes?

Japanese:
それより　転生者は昔からいたと
思うんだけど　急に法律なんか
作っちゃって　おかしくない？
English:
Come to think of it, Reincarnators have 
been around for ages. Isn’t it weird how 
this law appeared out of nowhere?

Japanese:
どうなんだろ…
でも　こんなに大きな騒ぎになったのは
今回が　初めてだと思うよ
English:
I wonder...
This is probably the first time I’ve caused 
this much trouble.

Japanese: 研究所って？
English: A Research Lab?

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese:
転生者研究…　か
天術は　確かに研究の余地が
あるのかもしれないね
English:
Reincarnator Research, huh... Then there might be 
laboratories to study Cielan Artes in.

Japanese:
なに　人ごとみたいに言ってんの
その研究されるのって　あたしたちなのよ？
わかってんの？
English:
What are you saying?
We’re the ones being researched here. 
Get that?

Japanese:
それは　そうだけどさ
研究して　理解を深めることは
科学の発展に　必要だよ
English:
Well, yes, but research is also necessary to gain more 
understanding and progress scientific development.

Japanese:
天術を科学で　解明しようっての？
そんなこと　できるわけないじゃない
English:
What the heck are you saying? There’s no way you can
gain an understanding of Cielan artes!

Japanese:
そうかなぁ　父さんが子どもの頃に
機関車が動くのを　初めて見たとき
魔法だと思ったって　言ってたんだ
English:
Who knows... After all, when my dad was a kid, people 
thought that moving locomotives were witchcraft.

Japanese:
だから　天術だって
魔法に見えるかもしれないけど
研究すれば…
English:
That’s why, even though Cielan Artes might seem like 
magic, as long as enough research is--

Japanese:
そもそも　なんであたしが
科学の発展のために
研究されなきゃ　いけないのよ
English:
At any rate, why do I have to be experimented on for
the sake of science develo-- whatever...

Japanese: …そりゃまあ　そうだけどね
English: Well, true...

Japanese:
フンだ　こんなところ　なんとかして
逃げ出してやるんだから
科学の発展も　研究もクソッタレだっての！
English:
To hell with this! We have to find a way out of here. 
Scientific development can go eat shit!

Japanese: 下品だなあ…
English: How vulgar...

Japanese: なんか言った？
English: Did you say something?

Japanese: い…　いや　別になにも…
English: No... Nothing.

Japanese: ガラムとの戦況
English: The War Against Garam

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese:
ねえ　ガラムと　レグヌムって
なんで戦争してんだっけ？
English: Why are Garam and Regnum at war with each other?

Japanese: あきれる
English: Ridicule

Japanese: 驚く
English: Be surprised

Japanese:
そんなの子どもでも　知ってるのに
まさか　ホントに知らないの？
English:
Even a child would know something like that. 
Do you really not know?

Japanese:
ど～～～せ　あたしなんて
王都の情報も　入って来ないような
ド辺境の出身ですよ～だ！
English:
Shut up! I didn’t manage to collect information in the
capital, and it isn’t common knowledge from where
I’m from.

Japanese:
いちいち　スネんなって
ちゃんと教えてやるからよ
English:
The war’s been going on for many years now,
you might not understand so I’ll talk slowly.

Japanese:
フ～ンだ！　偉そうに！
聞いてやるから　とっとと話しなさいよ！
English:
Quit acting so high and mighty!
I’ll listen, so spill!

Japanese:
偉そうなのは
どっちなのさ…
English: Who’s acting high and mighty?

Japanese: うっさーい！！
English: Beat it!

Japanese:
え…　まさか
ホントに　知らないの？
English: You don’t know?

Japanese:
だってさぁ　あたしの故郷って
戦争に縁ないからね
新聞での扱いも　小さいもんよ
English:
Not really.
My hometown’s far away from the war. 
And newspapers aren’t a common thing there.

Japanese:
ンじゃあ　丁寧に教えてやるから
ちゃ～んと　聞けよ？
English: Then I’ll explain it thoroughly, so you better listen.

Japanese:
ンじゃあ　丁寧に聞いてあげるから
ちゃ～んと　教えなさいよ？
English: Then I’ll listen to you throroughly, so tell me.

Japanese: なんで　どっちも偉そうなのさ…
English: Why are you both so uptight...?

Japanese:
確か　ガラムが交易路を一方的に
封鎖したのが　発端だったよな
English:
If I recall correctly, the war started because Regnum 
monopolized the trade routes and blocked off Garam.

Japanese:
あれ？　山賊を装ったレグヌム軍が
鉱物を輸送中のガラム軍を
襲撃したからって　聞いたけど…
English:
Huh? I heard it was because bandits disguised as
Regnum soldiers attacked a container being 
delivered to the Garam Army...

Japanese:
そりゃ　ガラムが
そう宣伝しただけだ
English: That’s only Garam propaganda.

Japanese:
ガラム軍は　ゲリラ戦にどうしても
持ち込みたかったんだよ
English: The Garam Army operates using guerilla tactics, y’see.

Japanese:
だから　レグヌムの増援と
補給路を　断つために
早々に　交易路を封鎖したのさ
English:
That’s why they’re rushing to cut off the supply of
Regnum reinforcements by severing the trade routes.

Japanese:
へえ～　そうだったの？
そんなの知らなかったよ…
English: Ohh! I didn’t know that...

Japanese:
ゲリラ戦は　ガラムのお家芸だからな
あの国の兵士は　軍隊っていうより
武芸者の集団って　感じだからなぁ
English:
Guerilla tactics is Garam’s specialty.
That’s why their country’s soldiers are well trained in
close-quarters combat.

Japanese: ふあ～ああ…　退屈な話ねぇ…
English: Boring...

Japanese:
スパーダって
戦争に興味あるの？
English: Spada, are you interested in warfare?

Japanese:
興味があるってわけじゃないけど
ちょっと　耳に入っただけさ
English:
Not really, but it’s just something I tend to hear
from others.

Japanese:
ふうん…
だってさ
イリア　わかった？
English: So he says... Did you get that, Illia?

Japanese:
はぁ？　ああ…　ちゃんと聞いてたってば
…で　なにが
耳に入ったんだって？　虫？　水？
English:
Huh? Oh... uh... I was listening! 
You said something about an oar or fair?

Japanese:
ゼンゼン聞いてねぇよ
こいつ…
English: She wasn’t even listening...

Japanese: 「無恵」について
English: About The Fracture

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: そういやぁ　ルカよぉ
English: Hey, Ruca.

Japanese: な…　なに？
English: W-What?

Japanese:
「無恵」って
一体　どういう意味だよ？
English: What does “The Fracture” mean anyway?

Japanese:
そーよ
ゼンゼン意味わかんないってのよ
English:
Oh yeah! 
I didn’t get that at all.

Japanese: ええ？　知らないの？
English: Huhh? You don’t know?

Japanese: 悪い？
English: Got a problem with that?

Japanese: …わ　悪くはないけどさぁ
English: N-No.

Japanese:
とにかく　説明しろよ
天上界に関係するっぽいからな
知っておきてェんだよ
English:
Anyways, since it seems to have something to 
do with Cielo, elaborate.

Japanese:
前は　関係ない話はするなって
言ってたのに…
English: They didn’t even listen last time...

Japanese:
あっら～　ルカくんが
独り言　言ってる　ご様子ねぇ～
English: My, my～ It seems that Ruca’s talking to himself again.

Japanese:
ああ？　なんだよ　ルカ
おまえ　言いてェことがあんなら
ハッキリ　言いやがれ！
English:
If you have something to tell us, then man up and 
tell us!

Japanese:
なななな　なんでもないよッ！
話すよ！　話すからさ…
English:
N-N-Nothing! 
Fine, I’ll tell you...

Japanese:
ええっと　ほら　教団で使われていた
不思議な魔法「奇跡」がある時期から
パッタリ　使えなくなったんだ
English:
Let’s see... It was the point when the Church started to 
become unable to use miracles.

Japanese: なんでよ？
English: Why?

Japanese:
それは　知らないよ
天上界が　消滅したからじゃないの？
English:
That I don’t know. 
Isn’t it because Cielo disappeared?

Japanese:
だ・か・ら　なんで天上界が消滅したら
奇跡が　使えなくなっちゃうのかって
聞いてんのよ　わかんないヤツねえ
English:
Ugh, you’re so dense. My point is, why does Cielo’s 
disappearance have anything to do with being unable 
to use miracles?

Japanese:
ああ　地上人の信仰心を集めて
天上界を　維持してたのは
そういう理由かぁ
English:
Ohh, that’s because Cielo uses prayers as a way to 
maintain itself, right?

Japanese: そういうことだね
English: Yep!

Japanese: だから「無恵」ってか
English: That’s why it was “The Fracture.”

Japanese:
……………
全然わかんないっての！
あたしにもわかるように　説明しなさいよ！
English:
...
I don’t get it! 
Explain it to me better!

Japanese:
だからよォ　地上人がアレすっから
天上人が見返りに
ガーッて　やったってことだろ？
English:
It’s because it’s what Cielo gives in return for that thing 
humans give, right?

Japanese:
ごめん　スパーダ
それじゃあ　僕にも　わかんないよ…
English: Sorry, Spada, you lost me there...

Japanese:
ええっと　つまり　天上界は地上人の
信仰を集めて　その見返りに　天術の力を
地上人に　与えてたってことだよ
English:
Well, in summary, Cielo gathers people’s prayers and 
lets them use Cielan Artes in exchange.

Japanese:
そうそう
オレが言いたかったのは　それそれ
English: Exactly!

Japanese:
あ～　なるほど　その天術の効果が
いわゆる　お恵みで「奇跡」って
呼ばれてたってわけね～
English:
Oh I see... Basically, the effect of Cielan Artes, 
bless-whatever, was then called “miracles.”

Japanese:
そうそう　そういうこと！
わかったか　イリア？
English:
Yep, exactly!
You get it now, Illia?

Japanese:
なんだか
あんたに　偉そうにされるの
死ぬほど　ムカツクんだけど…
English: For some reason the way you said that pisses me off...

Japanese: ベルフォルマ家
English: The Belforma Family

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: お坊ちゃまかぁ…
English: “Young Master”...

Japanese: スパーダをからかう
English: Tease Spada

Japanese: スパーダをからかわない
English: Don’t tease Spada

Japanese: お坊ちゃま…　ねぇ
English: Young Master...

Japanese:
あー　うるせェうるせェ！
すごく　うるせェ！
心の底から　うるせェな！！
English:
You two are starting to get on my nerves!
So can you please, shut up?

Japanese:
あら　ごめんなさい
お坊ちゃまの　お気には召さないようね
ルカ　静かにしましょ？
English:
Oh, pardon me.
As the Young Master requested, let’s both shut up.

Japanese:
ごめんね　お坊ちゃま
もう黙るよ
English:
Apologies, Young Master.
I’ll shut up.

Japanese:
んがぁあっ！
いい加減にしやがれ！
English: AAaaargh! Cut it out!

Japanese:
スパーダは　そう呼ばれるの
嫌がってたみたいだけど…
English: I don’t think Spada likes being called that...

Japanese:
い～じゃん
あたしが　そう呼びたいんだから
ね？　お坊ちゃま
English:
Oh, It’s fine～. Because I want to call him that!
Ain’t that right, "Young Master?"

Japanese:
い～じゃん　じゃねェよ！
ね？　じゃねェよ！
んで　お坊ちゃまじゃねェ～ってばよ！
English:
Oh, it’s totally fine--NOT!
Got that? NOT. FINE. AT. ALL. 
I’m not a "Young Master"!

Japanese:
スパーダって
いいとこのボンボンだったのね
English: That said, so you’re rich, huh, Spada.

Japanese:
あら　ごめんなさい
スパーダじゃなくて
スパーダお坊ちゃまだったっけ？
English:
Oh, pardon me, I should’ve addressed you as Young 
Master Spada.

Japanese: ぐぐぐ…

ベルフォルマ家って　言えば
王都でも　指折りの貴族だからね
貴族さまと　直に話せるなんて光栄だよ
English:
The Belforma family is one of the Capital’s
distinguished noble families.
I’m honored to be able speak to one in person.

Japanese:
ああ　もう！
オレは　そんなんじゃねェって…
English:
Oh shut it. 
I’m not even a noble...

Japanese:
でも　なんであんた　そんなに大胆に
道を　踏み外しちゃったのよ？
黙ってても　大金持ちじゃない
English:
So, why did you choose to abandon your noble life? 
Wouldn’t you be rich, even if you do nothing?

Japanese:
そりゃ　暮らしていくだけなら
いくらでも　食わせてもらえるだろうよ
でも　それは誰かの世話になるってこった
English:
Well, I gotta live, after all.
Of course, they’d still take care of me,
but that’d just mean that I’d be a burden.

Japanese:
…………え～と
どういう意味？
English: Uhmm... What do you mean?

Japanese:
兄貴が　大勢いるから
オレに　まわって来るものは
なーんもねえってことさ
English:
I have a lot of older brothers, y’see.
Consider that and I’d have nothing.

Japanese:
オレには　せいぜい政略結婚の
道具にされるぐらいしか
できることはないだろうよ
English:
I’ll just end up as a tool to get married off to some 
other noble.

Japanese:
へぇ～
結婚できるの？
いいなぁ…
English:
Oh... 
Marriage sure is nice.

Japanese: 食いつくとこ　そこじゃねえだろ！
English: That’s not the point!

Japanese:
まあなんだ…　「誇り高い」ってのはよ
誰かの　世話になったりしねェことだと
思わねーか？
English:
Anyways, don’t you think being taken care 
of is something to be ashamed of?

Japanese:
いーじゃん
かじるスネがあるんなら
ガジガジ　かじっちゃえばさぁ
English: Ain’t that fine. If you have the chance, just take it.

Japanese:
親に保護されているヤツや
他人の金で　遊んでるヤツが
「誇り」なんて言っても　説得力ねェよ
English:
If you’re telling me to be satisfied with being taken 
cared of while living off someone else’s money, 
then I ain’t convinced.

Japanese:
ウチの士道訓五箇条ってのは
常に　己を正す
心得みてェなもんだ
English:
After being raised under the Five Pillars of Chivalry, 
I’ve decided to take it to heart and live by it.

Japanese:
だからオレは　まず誰かの世話に
ならなくても済む　一人前の人間に
ならなきゃなんねーんだよ！
English:
That’s why I have to become 
an independent person first!

Japanese:
ふ～ん
志は立派だね
English: What a fine ambition.

Japanese:
うん　立派だと思う
志はね
English: I think so too.

Japanese:
うるせェな
ど～せ　オレは不良だよ！
English: Shut it, I’m just a delinquent!

Japanese: ミルダ家とベルフォルマ家
English: The Milda and Belformas

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese:
ハルトマンが　言ってたけどよぉ
おまえん家と　オレん家の付き合いって
一体どういうことなんだ？
English:
Hartman mentioned it earlier, but what did 
he mean about your family and my
family getting along?

Japanese:
ああ　それは　たぶん
株式投資をしてくれてるんだと思う
English:
Ah, I think that’s probably because your
family invests in my family’s stock.

Japanese: ああ？　株ぅ？
English: Stocks?

Japanese:
僕の家も　一応
街では有名な　商家だからね
English:
The Mildas are pretty much famous for being
a merchant family in Regnum, after all.

Japanese:
信用できる　投資先だと
判断してくれたんじゃないかな
English:
Perhaps because of the Milda house’s reputation,
the Belformas were able to invest in their stocks.

Japanese:
ってこたぁ　オレん家は
おまえん家に　金貸してるってわけか？
English: So basically my family lends yours money?

Japanese:
そ…　それは
ちょっと　違うような…
English: N-Not exactly...

Japanese:
なんだよ！　しょうがねェなぁ～
そうか　金貸してたのか
まあ　でも　実家は実家だ
English:
Can’t be helped! 
I see... so my family lends your family money, huh... 
I guess that’s just how it is.

Japanese:
オレはおまえから　借金を取り立てたり
おまえに　偉ぶったりなんかしねェから
心配すんなよ！
English:
I won’t extort money or act arrogantly
towards you, so don’t worry, man!

Japanese:
…………
…ま　いっか
そういうことにしとこうっと
English:
...
Well, whatever. 
Let’s leave it at that.

Japanese: 蒸気機関について
English: About Steam Engines

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese:
そういや　おたんこルカ
蒸気機関って　なに？
English: Hey, dummy, what are steam engines?

Japanese: どうしたのさ　いきなり
English: Why this all of a sudden?

Japanese:
あんた　あの人型の鉄の塊を見て
蒸気機関じゃないって　言ってたじゃん
それを思い出したの
English:
You mentioned that “these don’t seem to be
steam engines” when you saw those machines
earlier, remember?

Japanese:
ああ　そんなこと言ったかもね
ええっと　蒸気機関ってのはさぁ
昔々の　数学者が…
English:
Oh I did, didn’t I?
Let’s see... A long time ago, mathematicians--

Japanese:
ちょっと待って！
説明は簡潔に…　ね
わかった？
English:
Hold on!
Explain it in simpler terms.
Got it?

Japanese:
わ…　わかったから
銃に手をかけるの　止めてよ…
えーっと　水を温めると　どうなる？
English:
I-I get it, so can you please put down that gun?
Ok so, what do you think will happen when you
boil water?

Japanese:
あんた　バカにしてんの？
お湯になるに
決まってんでしょ！
English:
Are you dumb?
It’ll become hot water, duh!

Japanese:
それを　もっと温めると　水蒸気になるよね？
ほら　お湯を沸かすと
ヤカンのフタが　持ち上がるでしょ
English:
But, if you heat it a bit longer it will become
steam, right? Like how a kettle’s lid starts to 
lift after the water boils.

Japanese: それが　なに？
English: So what?

Japanese:
水蒸気で　ヤカンのフタを
持ち上げる力を
色々　利用するのが　蒸気機関なんだよ
English:
The energy from the steam that makes the lid rise
is also used in steam engines.

Japanese:
はぁ？　なにそれ？
なんで　お湯沸かしたら
バカでかい汽車が　動くってえのよ？
English:
What the heck?
So how does boiling hot water move
ginormous trains, then?

Japanese:
大きいヤカンなら　フタも大きいでしょ？
重い物を動かすなら
大きい機関が　必要になる
English:
If a kettle’s big, then its lid will also be big, right?
If you want to move heavy things, then you’re going
to need big engines.

Japanese:
だから　汽車の蒸気機関って
すっごく　大きいんだよ
English:
That’s why you’re going to need a huge steam engine
for that thing.

Japanese: へぇ～…
English: I see...

Japanese:
あの人型兵器は
蒸気機関を　積み込めるほどの
大きさには見えなかったしね
English:
Those automated war machines didn’t seem like they
held a big enough steam engine.

Japanese:
だから
蒸気機関じゃないんだろうって…
English: That’s why I thought that...

Japanese: ふわぁぁあ…
English: Oh...

Japanese:
イリア
わ…　わかってくれた？
English: Illia, are you following me?

Japanese: あー　んー…　まあだいたいね
English: Uh... Yeah... The gist of it, at least.

Japanese:
そっか…
だいたいかぁ…
English: I see... the gist of it...

Japanese:
今のルカくんの説明
悪くなかったと　思うんだけど…
だいたいしか　伝わらないのか
English:
I thought the explanation that Ruca gave earlier was 
fairly adequate, but... was he only able to teach her
the gist of it?

Japanese:
こんな調子じゃ
いろいろ　大変そうだな
English:
This kind of rhythm seems to bring up all sorts
of difficulty...

Japanese: 枢密院について
English: About the Privy Council

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
ねえねえ　アンジュ
枢密院について
もっと　詳しく教えてよ
English: Ange, can you tell me more about the Privy Council?

Japanese:
うーん　教えたくても
あんまり　教えられないかも…
English: Hm... even if I could, I cannot...

Japanese:
それって
教団の秘密組織だから？
English:
Is it because it’s one of the 
Church’s secret organizations?

Japanese:
ううん　枢密院って
今では名目だけの　お飾り役職なの
English:
No it is because, right now, it is nothing more than an
honorary position.

Japanese:
実権なんて　ほとんどないから
語るべきこと自体が　あまりないのよね
English:
What I mean by that is that it does not have any 
semblance of power so there is little to say about it.

Japanese: そ…　そうなの？
English: I-Is that so?

Japanese:
政教分離が　憲法で定められてから
教団が　政治に関われなくなったんだけど
教団の権力そのものは　健在だった
English:
After the constitution established the separation of 
church and state, the Church could no longer get 
involved in politics, but its influence has never waned.

Japanese:
だからムリヤリ　国王側に教団の意向を
押し付ける役職が　生まれたの
相談役って　口実でね
English:
That is why a council was created to force the Church’s 
will on the Sovereign under the guise of being advisors.

Japanese: それが　枢密院の始まり
English: And that was how the Privy Council was created.

Japanese:
それって「無恵」の前の話だよね？
だとしたら　ずいぶん古い話みたいだけど…
English:
And that happened before The Fracture? If that’s the 
case, it must’ve happened a long time ago...

Japanese:
そうね　だから無恵によって
教団の権威が　失墜して以来
ただの名誉職に　なっちゃったのよ
English:
Indeed. Which is why it is nothing more than an
honorary position now because the Church has
lost its influence due to the Fracture.

Japanese:
でも　一応「偉い役職」という権威は
残っているから　影響力は
小さくないかもしれないわね
English:
But, at the very least, it still has the authority of a 
"high office," so perhaps the influence it still has
might not be that small.

Japanese:
なんで　そんな名前ばかりの
役職を残すの？
必要ないなら　失くせばいいのに
English:
If the position’s not needed anymore, then why is it 
still there? Why not just remove it?

Japanese:
政治というものは　前例主義だもの
よっぽど熱心に　改革しようとしない限り
一度決まったものは　改まらないものよ
English:
Regnum’s government is very conservative. It 
actively opposes any changes once it has 
decided to do anything.

Japanese:
だから　今でも枢密院に　権威は残ってるし
別段　害もないから　誰も改革に
手を伸ばさなかったのかな
English:
I think the reason why the Privy Council 
still exists is because they do no harm, 
so no one is motivated to remove them.

Japanese:
…権威だけが残って
権力者には　無視される役職かぁ
悪いことするには　最適だね
English:
So only its influence remains and those who hold 
power within it are ignored...
Sounds like the best way to do bad things.

Japanese:
これ以上　教団を　おとしめないで
欲しいんだけどなぁ
ただでさえ　信者が少なくなってるのに…
English:
I would prefer that you stop badmouthing the Church. 
It has already lost most of its believers as it is.

Japanese: 教団について
English: About the Church

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
ねえ　アンジュ
素朴な疑問があるんだけど
English: Hey, Ange, I have a small question.

Japanese: どんな疑問かしら？
English: What is it?

Japanese: 教団って　なんのためにあるの？
English: What’s the church for?

Japanese:
よ…　予想以上に
素朴な疑問ね…
English:
That question is... 
more complicated than I anticipated.

Japanese:
そお？
あたしの村の教会なんて
廃屋同然だったんだもん
English:
Is it? The church in my village’s the same old
rackety place as the other ones, y’see.

Japanese:
教団の人間も　巡回制だったから
月に一日しかいなかったもんね
あんなの　なんのためにあるんだか
English:
Those church fellas often patrolled around my
village once a month, so I was wondering why they
were doing that.

Japanese:
うーん…　じゃあ昔の話なんだけどね
天上界へ帰るために
人々が集団生活を　始めたとしましょう
English:
Let us see... It began when people gathered together
and created a community with the goal of returning
to Cielo.

Japanese: うんうん
English: Okay...

Japanese:
集団で生活していると
結婚式とか　お葬式とかを
仕切る人が　必要になるでしょ？
English:
They needed someone to manage events in the 
community such as marriages and funerals.

Japanese:
そうすると　誰がどこに住んでいるのか
把握した方が　仕切るのが楽になるから
じゃあ　戸籍を作ろうってことになる
English:
Through that, it was easy to know where someone
lived and create a census of the community itself.

Japanese:
え～と…　それって
お役所がやることじゃないの？
English: Uhh... Isn’t that the government’s role?

Japanese:
そうね　だから　昔
国としての形が　整っていなかった頃は
教会を中心に　村や町があったの
English:
Yes, that is why when civilization started 
to take shape, churches were often found 
at the center of every city and town.

Japanese:
そこで　お役所を運営するために
みんなで　お金を出し合おうって
発想が　税金の始まりね
English:
They managed the community’s finances 
gathered from contributions. From there, 
the concept of taxes were born.

Japanese:
病人を看病したり　教義を広めるために
民衆に教育を施したり
昔は教団にも　色んな機能があったのよ
English:
Furthermore they served as a place of healing 
as well as education. Churches had a lot of 
functionalities in the past.

Japanese: へえ　便利ね～
English: How convenient...

Japanese:
だから　教団の権力が大きくなるのも当然ね
でも　逆にそのせいで　「無恵」が起こって
教団が信者に　そっぽ向かれたときは…
English:
That is why it is only natural that the church’s
authority was large. But once The Fracture 
happened, its believers slowly disappeared.

Japanese:
これ幸いと　政教分離の名の下に
権力のほとんどを　国王に
奪われちゃったんだけどね
English:
Taking advantage of The Fracture as well as the
church’s separation from the state, the sovereign
took away all the Church’s authority.

Japanese: んで　結局　教団って　なに？
English: So, in the end, what is the Church?

Japanese:
今の教団は　純粋に信仰の場ね
天に帰りたいと　願う人たちの
集まりって感じかな
English:
Today, it is nothing more than a place of worship. 
People go there if they seek salvation.

Japanese:
…その部分だけ　話してくれれば
いいじゃない
アンジュの話って　長いのよね
English:
You could’ve just told me that instead...
Ugh, your explanations are too long.

Japanese:
私は　これでも尼僧よ
長話とお説教が　お仕事だもの
さて　次は無恵以降の　教団史でも…
English:
I am a nun. Giving long sermons is my job.
Now, next is the church’s history after The Fracture...

Japanese:
いえ！　結構です！
さよなら！
English:
No thanks!
Bye!

Japanese:
き…　気持ちいいぐらいの
拒絶ぶりね…
English: What a way to refuse...

Japanese: 王都の情勢
English: The Royal Capital’s Circumstances

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
どうしたの　ルカくん
浮かない顔して
English: What is with the long face, Ruca?

Japanese:
そういえば　レグヌムのあたりは
今　どうなってるのかなと
心配になってさ…
English:
Well, I’m worried about how
Regnum must be faring...

Japanese:
戦争が激化して
戦場になってたりとかしないのかな…
English:
Like if the war has gotten worse enough
that it might’ve reached Regnum already...

Japanese:
いや
その心配はないだろう
English: No, there’s no need to worry about that.

Japanese: 疑う
English: Doubt

Japanese: 納得する
English: Agree

Japanese:
どうして　そう思うの？
僕を安心させるために
そう言ってるだけじゃないの？
English:
Why would you think that?
Aren’t you saying that just to
reassure me?

Japanese:
俺は　そこまで優しくはない
それなりの　根拠があっての
推測なのだがな
English:
I’m not that gentle. It’s because
I have a good grasp on the
battlefield’s situation.

Japanese: …う　疑って　ごめん
English: I-I’m sorry.

Japanese:
いや　なんでも人の言葉を
受け入れればいいというものじゃない
疑うのも　立派な知恵だ
English:
Don’t be. One should not easily
trust the words others give them.
It is wise to be skeptical.

Japanese:
リカルドさんが　言うなら
そうなんだろうね
安心したよ
English:
Well, if you say so, then that
must be the case. What a relief...

Japanese:
…信用してもらえるのは　嬉しいが
安心させるために　いい加減なことを
言ってるだけかもしれんぞ？
English:
I’m glad that you trust me, but
did you consider that I might
just be lying to reassure you?

Japanese: そ…　そうなの？
English: R-Really?

Japanese:
それは　俺の話を聞いてから判断しろ
俺が言ったから　それで安心というのでは
軽率じゃないか？
English:
It is rash of you to just believe my words as is.
For now, why don’t you decide after you’ve
heard the reason why?

Japanese:
えーっと　じゃあ　どうして
レグヌムは戦場になってないって
わかるの？
English:
I see... Then, how do you know
that Regnum hasn’t become a
battlefield yet?

Japanese:
王都レグヌムと　隣接しているのは
ナーオス　ガラム　マムート
English:
The towns surrounding Regnum
are Naohs, Garam and Marmut.

Japanese:
ナーオスは　そもそもレグヌム領だし
ガラムは　地形を利用した防戦で
戦況を　ドロ沼化させたがる傾向が　強い
English:
Naohs is in Regnum’s territory to begin with.
Meanwhile, Garam tends to use their own terrain
as a defensive measure to keep the war in check.

Japanese:
マムートは　現状　中立都市だから
レグヌムと　交戦状態にはない
English:
Lastly, Marmut is a neutral town and has
no hostilities with Regnum at the moment.

Japanese:
なるほどね
つまり王都自体は　どの戦場からも遠いから
今のところ　心配ないってことか
English:
I see. To sum it up, Regnum is far from any
of the battlefields so, as of now, there is not
much to worry about.

Japanese:
まあ　そういうことだ
さらにレグヌムと　隣接していないテノスとの
戦場は　ずいぶん北に離れているらしいからな
English:
That’s how it is. As for Regnum’s hostilities
with Tenos, I have heard that its battlefield
is a bit farther north.

Japanese:
さらに　言えば
レグヌム周辺は　街道整備が進み
治安も強化されている
English:
On top of that, the highways around Regnum
are well supervised and maintained.

Japanese:
今はまだ　ルカが両親を心配するような
状態にはないということだ
English:
And that’s why there’s no need to worry about
your parents, Ruca.

Japanese:
だってさ　良かったね
ルカくん
English:
As he says.
Is that not nice, Ruca?

Japanese:
うん　安心したよ
ありがとう　リカルドさん
English:
Yep, that’s a relief!
Thanks, Mr Ricardo.

Japanese: レグヌムについて
English: About Regnum

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
次に向かうのは
王都レグヌムだよね？
English: Our next destination is Regnum, correct?

Japanese:
そうそう　ねえ　ルカ
…で　レグヌムって
どんな街だったっけ？
English:
Uhuh... That reminds me, hey Ruca, 
what kind of town is Regnum?

Japanese:
ん～と　レグヌムはね…　って
僕と出会った街じゃないか！
覚えてないの？
English:
Let’s see, Regnum is... Wait a second, 
didn’t we meet at Regnum!?
Don’t you remember?

Japanese:
ゆっくり　観光してたわけじゃないもん
あたし　教団に
追い回されてたんだからね
English:
It’s not like I had the time to go sightseeing.
I was being chased around by the church, remember?

Japanese:
そ…　そういえばそうだったね
ええっと　レグヌムは…
うう～んっと…
English:
Oh... right. Let’s see...
Regnum is... uh...

Japanese:
レグヌムは　もっとも古い街で
大陸全土の　盟主国だったという歴史から
国民は総じて　プライドが高く頑固だ
English:
Regnum is a town with a deeply rooted history
of leading the whole continent. In general, its
people are prideful and stubborn.

Japanese:
ええ～
ルカを見てると
とてもそうは　思えないんだけど
English: Ohhh.... Well, Ruca sure doesn’t look prideful.

Japanese:
そういう連中が　多いという話だ
中には　例外もいる
English:
There are bound to be some exceptions
in a large group of people.

Japanese: 傷つく
English: Get hurt

Japanese: 愛想笑いをする
English: Force yourself to smile

Japanese:
そ　そんなぁ
僕だって　その…　プライドは
大切にしてるつもりだけど…　一応
English:
H-Hey, even I... uh... 
even I have pride... More or less...

Japanese:
どの口が「プライド」なんて
言うのよ
English: Where’s the “pride” in that answer?

Japanese:
ふむ　説得力に欠けるな
やはり　おまえは典型的王都人とは
言えんと思うぞ
English:
Where’s the persuasiveness to that?
As I thought, you’re far from the typical
Regnum citizen.

Japanese: あう…
English: Ugh...

Japanese:
でも　ボクは
控えめで謙虚なところが
ルカくんのいいところだと思うな
English:
I think it is nice that Ruca’s mild-mannered
and humble.

Japanese:
ってか　おたんこルカの
誉められそうなところって
そこだけよね！
English:
That’s the only thing praiseworthy 
about this dummy though!

Japanese:
うう…
誉められても
あんまり嬉しくないかも…
English: That praise doesn’t make me happy at all...

Japanese:
あはははは…
まいったなぁ
English: Oh, well... haha...

Japanese:
な～に　ヘラヘラしてんのよ
ちょっとは怒りなさいよ！
English:
Why are you laughing?
At least stand up for yourself!

Japanese:
でも　これなら
角は立たないでしょ？
English:
At least it’d be less harsh this way,
right?

Japanese:
ふふふ…
確かに謙虚で　控えめなところは
ルカくんの　いいところだね
English:
Heh... Rather, I find that humility and modesty are 
Ruca’s strong points.

Japanese:
そうかなぁ　あたしは
卑屈なだけだと　思うんだけど…
English:
Is that so? I think it’s coz he’s
submissive though...

Japanese:
それで？
他に　どんな特徴があんの？
English:
So? Are there any other characteristics
about Regnum that we should know about?

Japanese:
工業化が　進んだ街で
総生産が高い
反面　食料自給率は　非常に低い
English:
Regnum’s rate of industrialization and
production is high, but its self-sufficiency
rate is unusually low.

Japanese:
それは　学校で習ったよ
うん　知ってる　知ってる
English: Yeah, I learned that at school!

Japanese:
戦争に関しては
国民の多くが　無関心だな
English:
But, when it comes to the war, its
citizens are mostly indifferent to it.

Japanese:
正規兵も多く　さらに傭兵を
雇えるだけの　国力があるため
多くの一般人は　戦争に無縁だからだ
English:
This is because Regnum has enough
military power and resources to hire
mercenaires, so its citizens remain unaffected.

Japanese:
つまり　ルカみたいに緊張感のない
のーてんきな人ばっかってことね
English: So, basically, they’re blissfully ignorant just like Ruca.

Japanese: 僕は　のーてんきなんかじゃ…
English: I’m not ig--

Japanese:
だが　少なくとも
自分の出身地についてくらいは
自分で　説明できるようにならなければな
English:
At the very least, you should be able to explain
what kind of town your birthplace is.

Japanese:
うう…　そういう風に言われると
なんにも　言い返せないや
English: I... have no excuse.

Japanese: アンジュの講義
English: Ange’s Lecture

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
ねえ　アンジュ
原始的宗教って
どうして　すたれちゃったの？
English: Ange, why did the original religion become obsolete?

Japanese:
うわ！　おたんこルカのヤツ
なに　ややこしくなること
アンジュに　聞いちゃってるのよ！
English:
What the heck, you dummy, why are you asking Ange
such a complex thing!?

Japanese:
うひ～　始まった…
こりゃ　長くなるぜェ～？
English:
And so it begins. Get your popcorn ready, this is gonna
be a long one.

Japanese:
教団の主流派が
亜流派を　認めない方針だったから
圧力を掛けて　潰しちゃったのよ
English:
The followers of the church’s main faction did not
approve of the original religion’s principles, which is
why they pressed to eliminate it.

Japanese:
そんなことしたら　亜流派の信者から
反感を買うんじゃないの？
English:
If that’s the case, wouldn’t those followers
be antagonized?

Japanese:
なんで　質問かぶせてんのよ
おたんこルカは！
「ふ～ん」でいいじゃん！
English:
Why do you keep asking more questions, you dummy!? 
Just end it already!

Japanese:
ルカって　あんな話でも
興味を持って聞けるのが
すげェよな
English:
Ruca’s pretty amazing if he could keep his interest for 
that long.

Japanese:
亜流派といっても　根っこは同じだから
反感を持つよりも
主流派に合流する信者の方が　多かったのよね
English:
Even though they were subsects, their origins were the
same, so instead of feeling antagonized, many of the
people joined the main faction instead.

Japanese:
なるほどね　主流派が亜流派を弾圧するのは
そうやって　信者を奪うのも
目的なんだね
English:
I see, instead of the main faction opposing the group,
they ended up being stolen away instead.

Japanese:
あ…　アンジュの話
終わったっぽい？
English: Is Ange’s sermon done yet?

Japanese:
やれやれ　ようやく
つまんねえ話も　終わ…
English: Oh finally... that boring sermon’s finally end--

Japanese:
じゃあ　アンジュ
次は「無恵」の後の話なんだけど…
English: So, about after The Fracture...

Japanese: ダメだ！　まだ続くみたい！
English: This is bad, it’s not ending yet...

Japanese:
ヤベェ！　これ以上　話聞いてると
なにかおかしなものが　脳からこぼれて
耳から出てくるぜ！
English:
Oh man, I swear, if I hear any more of this
crap, my brains will start spewing out
of my ears or something...

Japanese: 逃亡！
English: Run away!

Japanese:
あれ？
スパーダくんと　イリアったら　慌てて
どこかに　行っちゃったけど…
English: Hm? Spada and Illia seemed to be in a hurry...

Japanese:
どうしたんだろ？
アンジュの話　ためになるから
一緒に聞いて　もらおうと思ったのに
English:
I wonder why? Ange’s sermons are quite useful so
I thought they might stay and listen.

Japanese: ナーオスについて
English: About Naohs

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
なぁ　アンジュ姉ちゃん
ナーオスって　どんなとこなん？
English: Hey, Sis Ange, what kinda place is Naohs?

Japanese:
ノンビリした　いい町よ
緑も多くて　広々してて
住民も真面目で　大らかな人ばかりだし
English:
It is a quiet and peaceful town 
with honest and earnest residents.

Japanese:
だが　海沿いの平地という立地条件は
良くないな
敵に攻められれば　簡単に落とされる
English:
But, since it’s a port town, it’s an open target for
enemies. If it gets attacked, it would fall in no time.

Japanese:
それは　そうですけど
敵に攻められることを前提に
造られた町ではありませんし…
English:
That is true, but committing such an act on the town
would be unthinkable.

Japanese:
まあ　教団が権威を　見せるために
ムリヤリ造った町だからな
English:
Well, it is a town built as proof of 
the Church’s authority.

Japanese: ま…　まあそうなんですけどね
English: Th-That is true...

Japanese:
大聖堂があるって　聞いてたけど
そういう意味やったんかぁ
English:
Ah’ve heard that there’s a Grand Cathedral here,
so it was built there cause of that?

Japanese:
…確かに　教団の権威を見せるという
面もあるけど　純粋に信仰を求める人たちの
共同体としての　面もあるのよ
English:
It is true that it serves as a display of the Church’s
power, however it also serves as a community 
for those who are seeking faith.

Japanese:
従順な信者の　信仰心を利用して
町の生産性を上げる　上手い手だ
English:
It’s quite crafty, channeling the devotion of obedient
followers into the town’s productivity.

Japanese:
もう　リカルドさん！
そういう悪い面ばかり
強調するのは　やめてください！
English:
Sir Ricardo! I implore you to 
stop speaking so negatively!

Japanese: おお　怖い怖い…
English: Oh how scary!

Japanese:
けど　アンジュ姉ちゃん
文句は言うても
否定はせぇへんねんなぁ
English: But, Sis Ange, he does have a point, hear?

Japanese:
まあ　本当のことだからね
でもナ{fixed}－{variable}オスは　いい町よ？
住んでいた私が　保証してあげる
English:
Well... it is true, after all. I promise you that Naohs 
is really a wonderful town. As someone who
has lived her life there, I can guarantee it.

Japanese:
うん
アンジュ姉ちゃんが　言うんやったら
間違いないわぁ～
English: Okay! If Sis Ange says so then it must be true!

Japanese:
きっと　姉ちゃんに似て
ノンキで　悠長で　のほほんとしとって
食べるの好きな人が　多いんやろなぁ
English:
Ah’m sure that, like Sis, there’s lotsa people there
who’re also carefree, easygoin’, nonchalant people
who like ta eat.

Japanese:
そ…　そういう目で
私を見てたのね　エルったら…
English:
So that is how you see me...
Oh, Hermie...

Japanese: 南西部開発について
English: About the South-West

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
はぁ…　うすうすは　気づいてたけど
あたしの村って
ホントに　ド辺境だったのねぇ
English:
I’ve only started to vaguely realize it, but my
hometown really is in a remote area.

Japanese:
イリアは　南西部出身だっけ？
そのうち開発が進んで
どんどん　都会になるんじゃないかしら
English:
Illia, you are from the southwest, correct?
Is your hometown slowly developing into a city?

Japanese:
どうかなぁ
その開発するための　お金が
戦争に　使われちゃってんでしょ？
English:
I wonder...?
I think the money needed for that development’s 
getting invested into the war efforts.

Japanese:
だったら
まず戦争が　終わってくれなきゃね
English: That’s why the war has to end first before that happens.

Japanese:
そうね　でも戦争が終われば
いずれ　イリアは大金持ちに
なれるんじゃない？
English:
Indeed.
Then, would that mean that you will
become rich once the war ends?

Japanese: ほえ？　なんで？
English: Huh? Really?

Japanese:
だって　あの辺りの土地の所有権は
早い者勝ちって　決まりなんでしょ？
English:
The ownership of the land in that region is decided by
who comes first, after all.

Japanese:
３年以上住んだっていう証拠を
書類にまとめて　提出すれば
そこはもう　その人の土地になるって…
English:
If someone presents papers as proof that they have 
been living in that land for at least three years, 
would the land not already be theirs?

Japanese: マージーでー？
English: REALLY?

Japanese:
知らなかったの？
そうやって　移民希望者を
集めてたはずよ
English:
You did not know?
It is how hopeful immigrants manage to gather into
a town.

Japanese:
あ～…　だからか…
村から離れて　家を建てる人とか
なんでだろうって　思ってたのよね
English:
Ohhh, so that’s why people would leave the village
and create houses far away from it.

Japanese:
イリアの　ご両親もきっと
その所有権を目的に　移住されたのよ
だから　開発が始まれば…
English:
I am sure that is also why your parents 
immigrated into undeveloped land.
That is why when developments start...

Japanese:
それには　まず
戦争が終わらないとね
English: But before that happens, the war has to end first.

Japanese:
あの辺りは全部　あたしの土地…
いや　あたしの家族の土地！
うっは　それすっご～い！！
English:
And those neighboring lands are all mine-- no, all of my 
family’s land! That’s awesome!!

Japanese:
どうすれば　地主になれる…　じゃなくて
大金持ちになれる…　でもなくて
戦争が終わるんだろ？
English:
But, to own them first--
No, to become rich-- 
That’s not it either-- the war has to end first, right?

Japanese:
そうねえ
まずは　教団に入信して
天に祈ってみる？
English:
Indeed, first why not enter the Church and pray
to Cielo?

Japanese:
あ～　いやぁ
そいつは　ごめんだわ
English: N-No... sorry, I can’t.

Japanese: アシハラって？
English: Ashihara is...?

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: アシハラって　どういう国なの？
English: So, what kind of country is Ashihara anyway?

Japanese:
ああ　それ　ボクも
少し詳しく　知っておきたいな
English: Oh, I would like to know more about it too, if possible.

Japanese:
見ての通り　小さな島国だね
でも　昔はもっとたくさんの島に囲まれてて
景色も　ずっときれいだったそうだよ
English:
As you can see, Ashihara’s a small island nation.
Although, a long time ago, it used to be surrounded by
a lot of islands and its scenery was a lot prettier.

Japanese:
それが今は　海面が上昇して
その島の　ほとんどが
沈んでしまったわけか…
English:
Now, the sea levels have risen to the extent 
that most of those islands have sunk...

Japanese:
昔は　すっごい強い海軍を持った
海洋国家で　支配地域も
すごく　広かったらしいけどね
English:
It also used to have a strong naval fleet.
I heard that the region this maritime 
nation encompassed was quite huge.

Japanese: ふうん…　気の毒ぅ～
English: Well that’s sad...

Japanese: ガラムについて
English: About Garam

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
なあ　ガラムってな
どんな土地柄なんだ？
English: Hey, what kind of place is Garam?

Japanese:
山岳民族が　王都に抵抗して
より集まったのが　町の由来だから
レグヌムとは　仲が悪い
English:
The town was founded by a bunch of mountain tribes
who have gathered together in order to resist the
Imperial Capital.

Japanese:
へえ　だからガラムとレグヌムは
戦争してんだっけ？
English: Ohhh, so is that why Garam and Regnum are fighting?

Japanese:
そういうわけではないがな
だが　戦争が長引くのは
そういう歴史的背景も　関係あるのだろう
English:
To sum it up, yes.
But, I assume that the history between the two
nations also has something to do with it.

Japanese:
んで　町には
どんな特徴があるんだ？
English: So what kind of place is this?

Japanese:
山に囲まれた
こじんまりとした町で
鉱物の生産が　主な産業だ
English:
As a country rested within the mountains, 
its main industry is mineral production.

Japanese:
豊富な鉱物資源のおかげで
製鉄や鍛冶も盛んでな
English:
Its iron production and smiths are thriving thanks to the 
abundance of minerals surrounding it.

Japanese:
そして　生み出される
優れた武具を目当てに
多くの武芸者が　立ち寄る町でもある
English:
And with the high quality weapons it’s producing, 
it is also a must-go-to place for warriors.

Japanese:
じゃあオレには　ピッタリの町だな
いい剣が
手に入ると　ありがたいぜ
English:
Gotta be the best town for me then. 
If I get a good sword, thanks in advance.

Japanese:
最近は　温泉目当ての観光客のおかげで
排他的だった　住民の気質も
和らぎつつある
English:
Lately, the town has become more open to tourists,
since the hot springs became world famous.

Japanese:
へぇ～　温泉もあんのか！
そりゃ　いい町だな！
English:
There’s hot springs too!?
This is a great town!

Japanese: 火山について
English: About the Volcano

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
ねえ　アンジュ
ガラムって　鍛冶の神バルカンの信仰で
有名なんだって？
English:
Ange, I heard that the worship of the 
God of the Smiths is popular around 
this area, is that true?

Japanese:
そうよ
それが　どうかしたの？
English: Indeed. Is something the matter?

Japanese:
教団の教えって　独自の神さまじゃなく
天上界そのものを
信仰の対象にしてるよね？
English:
And the Church doesn’t worship a specific god but the 
aspect of Cielo itself, correct?

Japanese:
特定の神さまを　信じるのって
僕には　なんだか
馴染まないなぁって　思ってさ
English:
It’s just that I’m not really accustomed with the concept
of worshipping a specific god.

Japanese:
でも「天上界」っていう　抽象的な物より
姿形があって　さらに人格まで備わった
神さまの方が　祈りやすいでしょ？
English:
It is easier to pray to a god you can relate to instead
of something abstract, correct?

Japanese:
う～ん　言われてみれば
そうかもしれないけど…
English: Now that you mention it, that does make sense, but...

Japanese:
でも　教団は「天に帰ること」を
教義にしてるはずだよね
だから　神さま個人を信じるってことは…
English:
Wasn’t the return to Cielo the basis of the Church’s 
teachings? So worshipping an individual god means...

Japanese:
そう　天に帰るという目的を
忘れちゃったということね
English: ...that they have forgotten about returning to Cielo, yes.

Japanese:
特定の神さまを　信じるということは
大地に根を下ろして　地上で
生きていこうという　意志の表れなのよ
English:
To sum it up, their decision to turn to a specific god 
meant that the people were willing to settle down on 
Terro and live the rest of their lives here.

Japanese: 共感する
English: Sympathize

Japanese: 疑問に思う
English: Doubt

Japanese:
地上で自由に　生きていこうっていう
発想は　前向きだなぁ
そういうの　ちょっといいね
English:
It’s such an optimistic way of thinking, 
I think it’s pretty good...

Japanese:
そうね
悪くないとは思うんだけど…
English: I agree, I do not believe it is bad either...

Japanese:
でも　それを認めちゃったら
教団の教義とは異なる　新しい宗教が
ドンドン　作られちゃうのよね
English:
However, if the Church were to recognize such beliefs,
many more religions opposing its doctrine will begin
to appear.

Japanese:
そうだね　教団としては
やっぱり　認められないよね
English: So, in the end, the Church will never do such a thing...

Japanese:
きっと　そのへんが
バルカンを信仰するガラムと
レグヌムが　不仲な原因なんだろうけど
English:
I’m sure that’s also one of the reasons why Regnum 
and Garam will never get along.

Japanese:
それって　やっぱり
教団から見れば　異端ってこと？
English:
Then wouldn’t that make it heresy in front of the 
Church’s eyes?

Japanese: 異端も異端　裏切りものよ！
English: “Heresy, heresy, treachery!”

Japanese:
…な～んて言ってたのは　ずっと昔の話ね
異端だからといって　弾圧するには
それだけの権力が　必要だもの
English:
They have been saying that for such a long time...
In order to opress that "heresy," you will need a lot of
political influence.

Japanese:
だから　教団が力を持っていた昔は
レグヌムとガラムって
本当に　仲が悪かったみたいよ
English:
That is why Regnum and Garam never got along
during the time that the Church was in power.

Japanese:
そうみたいだね
今でも　そういう傾向が
あるらしいけど…
English: And it seems like that’s still the case now.

Japanese:
話がズレちゃったかな
ガラムが　鍛冶の神バルカンを
信仰するようになった流れは…
English:
Oh, that was quite a tangent. Now back on topic, 
the reason why Garam has been worshipping 
the God of the Forge, Vulcan, is because...

Japanese:
まず　ガラムの人たちが
このあたりの自然や　気候を
神格化したのが　始まりね
English:
Well, first of all, it began when Garam started to
worship the climate as well as the nature of this area.

Japanese:
そこに　天上界の神さまの中で
もっとも　ふさわしい神さまを
信仰の対象に　当てはめちゃったの
English:
From there, they adopted an appropriate god 
from Cielo to match the surroundings.

Japanese:
ええ？
じゃあ　元々バルカンを
信じてたんじゃないの？
English: Huh? Then Garam never originally worshipped Vulcan?

Japanese:
おそらく　違うわね
先に火山や鍛冶を　敬う習慣があって
それに宗教が　くっついたの
English:
It is likely that they did not. At first they revered the 
volcano alongside the art of smithing and eventually
that reverence clung to their beliefs.

Japanese:
特に「鍛冶と炎」の条件を満たす
バルカンは　ガラムの土地柄に
ピッタリだったんでしょうね
English:
It just so happens that Vulcan’s affinities to fire and
smithing perfectly matched with the religion at the time.

Japanese:
いずれにせよ　ガラムの人たちは
もう「天に帰る」ことに
興味がないと　思うわ
English:
Either way, I believe that those from Garam lost 
interest in returning to Cielo.

Japanese:
ふ～ん…　鍛冶の神バルカンが
信じられるようになったのは　バルカンと
火山が　たまたま似てたからかぁ
English:
Ohhh, so the reason why Vulcan became a center of 
belief was because he was similar to the volcano.

Japanese:
天上人の中には　地上を気にかけていた
神さまもいたようだから　その痕跡が
記憶の場の　手がかりになるかもしれないわね
English:
Even among Cielans, there are those who hold
interest in Terro. Which is why there might be a
Memory Spring in places where they left their marks.

Japanese:
うん　そうだね
探してみようか
English:
That makes sense.
Let’s get searching then.

Japanese: ガルポスについて
English: About Galpos

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese: キュキュ
English: QQ

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese:
この町　なんや幸せそうで
気に入ってもぉたわぁ
English: Man, Ah kinda like this town. It looks happy.

Japanese:
キュキュも
ここ　気に入た
English: QQ also like this town.

Japanese:
なんせ　常夏の町だからな
自然も豊かで
おまけに作物も　実り放題
English:
Coz it’s always summer in this town and, with the lush 
nature surrounding it, it’s like an all-you-can-eat
buffet here.

Japanese:
餓死者なんか
出たことねェんじゃねえかな
English: I’m sure there won’t be any people starving here.

Japanese:
ガシシャ？
ガシシャ　なにか？
English: Star-ving? What’s star-ving?

Japanese:
ん～と　お腹空いて
困る人がおらんっちゅうこと
English: Hmm... it means no one’s ever hungry.

Japanese:
誰も　お腹空かない！？
それは　いいところ！
English:
No one’s ever hungry!?
That’s good!

Japanese:
ホンマや
めっちゃ　ええとこやん
住むんやったら　この町に決まりやなぁ
English:
True, true!
Really good!
Ah wanna live in this town!

Japanese:
みんな　エルと同じこと考えるから
レグヌムや　テノスの金持ちが
バカバカ土地を　買ってるらしいぜ
English:
Apparently rich folk from Regnum and Tenos had 
the same idea. Hence why they bought up a bunch 
of the land around here.

Japanese:
別荘暮らしかいな
そら　うらやましいなぁ
English: Holiday villas, huh? Man, Ah’m mighty jealous.

Japanese:
そういや確か　オレん家も
ここに別荘を　持ってたような…
English:
Oh yeah, that reminds me...
I think my family has a holiday villa here.

Japanese:
持つべきもんは　ええ家の友達やわぁ
スパーダ兄ちゃん
今まで以上に　仲良ぉしよな～
English:
All ya need is a friend from a nice family.
Spada Bro, let’s get along from now on.

Japanese:
そんな　邪念に満ちた友達なんて
いらねえよ…
English:
I don’t need people who want to be friends with me
just coz I’m rich.

Japanese: 地域の信仰について
English: About Galpos’ Religion

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese: エルマーナ
English: Hermana

Japanese:
このガルポスも　ガラムと一緒で
自然が　神格化された宗教だったんだね
English:
So Galpos’ religion, like Garam’s,
centered around nature, huh?

Japanese:
龍は　水に縁が深いから
台風や　洪水の多い
この地方ならではの　信仰ね
English:
Since this area often experiences typhoons and
floods, it is only natural they revered dragons,
who were commonly associated with water.

Japanese:
ふ～ん…　この町のみんなの声は
ヴリトラの耳に　届いとったんやろか？
English:
Ah wonder if Vritra heard the voices
of the people ’round here?

Japanese:
天上界は　地上人の信仰によって
支えられていたから
もちろん　届いてたでしょうね
English:
People’s faith supported Cielo,
so there’s no doubt about it.

Japanese:
ほんなら　ええわ
ヴリトラやったら　なんぞ信者の声にも
応えとったはずやしな！
English:
That’s good! If it’s Vritra, there’s no doubt
she woulda answered back.

Japanese:
そうだよ　きっと　ここの人たちも
信じる相手が　ヴリトラだったからこそ
石碑を　建てたりしたんだろうね
English:
Of course! It’s because they worshipped
Vritra that they erected monuments in her name.

Japanese:
うん！
なんや　ちょっと嬉しいなぁ
English:
Yeah!
Fer some reason that makes me happy.

Japanese:
…でも　アンジュ
そのせいで　この町の人たちは
教団に　弾圧されたんでしょ？
English:
But because of that... the people of this
island are oppressed by the Church, right?

Japanese:
うん　ヴリトラ信仰が
人々の記憶に　残ってないのが
その証拠だもの
English:
Yes. People have forgotten their
faith towards Vritra.

Japanese:
それを伝えるのは　今はもう
古い遺跡と　教団の文献だけ…
English:
These old ruins are proof of that,
alongside records hidden within the Church.

Japanese:
この話　エルには
教えない方がいいよね
English:
I feel like it’s better if we don’t
talk about this in front of Hermie.

Japanese: グリゴリとガードル
English: The Grigori and Gardle

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
グリゴリってよォ
転生者じゃねェんだろ？
English: The Grigori aren’t Reincarnators, right?

Japanese:
なのに　あんな不思議な力を使って
オレたちの天術を　封じ込めるなんてよ
なんか　納得いかねェんだよな
English:
But I can’t understand how they can use
whatever weird power they have to seal
our Cielan Artes.

Japanese:
それは　ガードルの
血のなせる業だろう
English: I assume that’s because of Gardle’s blood.

Japanese:
ガードルの血？
どういう意味だよ？
English:
Gardle’s “blood?”
What do you mean?

Japanese:
タナトスは　地上人の娘と
恋に落ちた
グリゴリの民は　その末裔なのだ
English:
The Grigori are Thanatos’ descendants from
when he fell in love with a Terran woman.

Japanese:
でも　タナトスが地上に
降りたのは　ずいぶん昔の話でしょ
English:
But Thanatos’ descent into Terro
happened a long time ago, right?

Japanese:
その間に　タナトスの血も
薄くなったんじゃないの？
English:
Wouldn’t that amount of time
thin out his blood?

Japanese:
折を見て　ガードル本人が
グリゴリの民との間に　子どもを作り
血の維持を　図ったのだろうな
English:
I suppose Gardle himself occasionally
mated with the Grigori in order to
preserve the quality of their blood.

Japanese: それって浮気…　だよね
English: That’s... infidelity, right?

Japanese:
ガードルにとっては
それもまた　愛の形なのだろう
English:
To Gardle, that might also be
another form of love.

Japanese:
なるほどな
タナトスの地上への　愛の結晶が
あのグリゴリたちってわけか
English:
Oh, so basically the Grigori are
Gardle’s children in Terro?

Japanese:
でも　そう思うと転生者のオレとしては
急に　あいつらに親近感が…
English:
Thinking about it as a Reincarnator,
I feel a bit closer to them...

Japanese: 湧いたか？
English: You really feel that way?

Japanese:
いや　ムリだな
あいつら　やっぱ気にくわねェ！
English:
Nah, no way!
I can’t really bring myself to like them.

Japanese: この先について
English: About What’s Up Ahead

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: キュキュ
English: QQ

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese:
確かマムートから　テノスまでは
汽車が　通ってなかったっけ？
English:
I believe there’s a train from
Marmut traveling to Tenos?

Japanese:
…キシャ！？　それなにか？
乗り物か？
キュキュたち　それ乗るか？
English:
A train!? What’s a train?
Can you ride it?
Are we riding it?

Japanese:
いや　確かに　以前は通っていたが
その路線も　もう随分前に
封鎖されてしまった
English:
No we’re not. While it is true that there used
to be a train between Marmut and Tenos,
its tracks have long been obstructed.

Japanese:
でも　レグヌムから汽車が
出てたような気がするんだけど…
English:
But I feel like there’s a train
coming out from Regnum...

Japanese:
その路線は　マムート止りだ
マムートから先は　テノスとレグヌムの
関係が悪化して以来　直通しなくなった
English:
That line stops at Marmut. The route past
Marmut has been closed off ever since
Tenos and Regnum’s relationship deteriorated.

Japanese:
キシャ　乗れないか
キュキュ　残念…
English:
Oh, we’re not riding train?
Aww...

Japanese:
今　マムートの北は
激戦区だから　通っていたとしても
軍用列車だけだろうな
English:
And, since there’s only a battlefield north
of Marmut, the only thing going through
it are supply trains.

Japanese: グチる
English: Complain

Japanese: 諦める
English: Give up

Japanese:
まったく　戦争のせいで
手間を掛けさせられるよね
戦争さえなかったら…
English:
I swear, this war just makes everything
harder. If only it never happened...

Japanese:
汽車でテノスまで　楽に行けたのにとでも
言うつもりか？
自分の都合で　平和祈願とはな
English:
So you mean to say that taking a train to
Tenos would’ve been easier? That’s just
wishing for peace for your own convenience.

Japanese:
あ…　いや
そんなつもりじゃなかったんだけど…
English:
Ah-- no...
I didn’t mean that...

Japanese:
まあ　いいさ
とにかく　優雅な鉄道旅行は諦めろ
English:
At any rate, I recommend you give up on
any thoughts of a comfortable journey.

Japanese:
船旅ばっかりだったから
汽車の旅も　風情があって
いいかななんて　思ったんだけど
English:
I just thought that a comfortable ride by
train would be a nice change of pace
compared to traveling by boat...

Japanese:
またいくらでも　その機会はあるさ
今後の楽しみにとっておけ
English:
We’ll get the chance to ride one eventually.
For now, just look forward to it.

Japanese:
そうだね　リカルドや　みんなとの
鉄道旅行　楽しみにしておくよ
ね　キュキュさん？
English:
You’re right, I can’t wait for when
I finally get to ride a train with
you guys, right, QQ?

Japanese: はい　楽しみ
English: Yes! Can’t wait!

Japanese:
やれやれ　いつになることやら
そんな時代が　早く来ればいいがな
English:
Good grief, I do hope that
time comes soon.

Japanese:
じゃあ
今は歩く以外　方法はないよね
English:
We don’t have any other alternatives
to walking for now, right?

Japanese:
そういうことだ
湿地は　歩きにくい上に
その先には　戦場が待っている
English:
That’s how it is. After we pass through
this abominable marsh we’ll have a
battlefield to look forward to.

Japanese:
大変そうだけど
頑張るしかなさそうだね
English: I suppose we’ll have to bear with it.

Japanese: 戦況について
English: About the Battlefield

Japanese: スパーダ
English: Spada

Japanese: イリア
English: Illia

Japanese: リカルド
English: Ricardo

Japanese: 今　戦争は　どういう状況なんだ？
English: How’s the war been going lately?

Japanese:
戦場が　北に移動してるってことは
レグヌムが　勝ってんでしょ？
English:
Didn’t the battlefield move way
north since Regnum’s winning?

Japanese:
じゃあ　この戦争
意外と　早く終わるかもな
English: Then this war might end soon.

Japanese: やれやれ　能天気な意見だな
English: Good grief, what a carefree comment.

Japanese: え…　それどういう意味よ？
English: What? Why?

Japanese:
わかるように　説明してくれよ
リカルドのおっさん
English: Explain it properly to us, old man Ricardo.

Japanese:
では　聞くが
戦場が　北に移動するとどうなる？
English:
Then, what do you think would happen
if the battlefield moves way up north?

Japanese:
決まってんだろ
戦場が　テノスに近くなる
English: The battlefield would get closer to Tenos, duh.

Japanese:
答えとしては　３０点だな
なら　戦場がテノスに近付くということは？
English:
30 points to you, Sir Belforma.
Now, what do you think will happen
if the war gets closer to Tenos?

Japanese: え～っと　…寒くなる？
English: Uhh... then it’d get colder?

Japanese: 惜しいな　５０点だ
English: Unfortunate. 50 points to Miss Illia.

Japanese:
寒くなると　レグヌム兵の士気は落ちる
それに対し　テノス兵は
元々寒い土地出身の　兵士ばかり
English:
When it gets colder, Regnum soldiers’ morale
will decrease while, in contrast, Tenos soldiers
would be fighting on their homeland.

Japanese:
…ああ　なるほど
自分のホームグラウンドで
戦った方が　有利ってこったな
English:
Oh, I get it. Fighting on your homeground
is an advantage.

Japanese:
加えて言えば　湿原を越えて
行軍させることで　兵を疲れさせれば
戦略的にも　テノスに有利だ
English:
In addition, if you’re from Tenos,
your enemies would be tired after
marching through a marshland.

Japanese:
さらに　北に戦場が移動すれば
レグヌム軍の　補給路は長くなり
物資輸送の負担は　増えるばかり
English:
The further north you are, the longer
and harder it will be for supplies to
reach the battlefield.

Japanese:
げげぇ～　じゃあ　レグヌム軍って
超ピンチなわけ？
負けちゃうの？
English:
Oof... Then wouldn’t that mean that 
Regnum’s heavily disadvantaged?
Is Regnum gonna lose?

Japanese:
そうでもないさ　テノス軍は
戦線を膠着させて　レグヌム軍が撤退する
タイミングを　計っているのだろう
English:
Not at all, they’re currently in a deadlock
with Tenos. As of now, Regnum is just
waiting for the right time to retreat.

Japanese:
なんだよ
勝ち負けがハッキリしねェ　戦いだな
English:
What the hell!? It’s so hard to tell
who’s winning or losing.

Japanese:
仕方ないさ
この戦争は　長く続きすぎた
どこも戦費をひねり出すのに　苦労している
English:
It can’t be helped. This war has gone on 
for far too long and managing war 
funds has become harder.

Japanese:
互いに　決定打を与えられるほどの
兵力も用意できない
もはや意地のみで　続いている状態なのさ
English:
Both forces can no longer work up
the strength to land a finishing blow,
so it’s just a war of attrition at this point.

Japanese:
そんな戦争なら
とっとと　止めちゃえばいいのに
English: That kind of war should just end.

Japanese: まったくだぜ…
English: Damn right...

Japanese:
俺も　おまえたちの意見には賛成だが
そう簡単に　割り切れないのが
戦争というものだ
English:
I agree, but it’s impossible for
the war to just simply end.

Japanese: レムレース湿原について
English: About Lemures Marsh

Japanese: コンウェイ
English: Kongwei

Japanese: ルカ
English: Ruca

Japanese: アンジュ
English: Ange

Japanese:
ねえ　このレムレース湿原って
どういう場所なのかな？
English:
Hey, I wonder what sort of place
this Lemures Marsh is?

Japanese:
え～と
アンジュ　知ってる？
English: Hmm... Ange?

Japanese:
昔の文献によると
この辺りには　小さな湖がたくさんあって
とても美しい場所だったみたいね
English:
According to ancient documents, it was once 
a beautiful place surrounded by a myriad 
of small lakes.

Japanese:
